However, she later told police when it emerged an arrest had been made in the murder inquiry. She said the boy also sent messages to the group saying what he thought couldve happened and how couldhave got out the house without anybody noticing in the house. She agreed other people in the group were contributing gossip, rumour and speculation.Questioned by Brian McConnachie QC, for the accused, she said at the time it was posted she was not aware Alesha had been murdered. She also agreed others were making comments in poor taste. He asked her: Ifhad not been arrested, you would have continued to think this was a bad joke Yeah, she replied. Earlier, the court had heard a kne was found on the shore opposite the home where the Alesha was allegedly taken from.Coastguard volunteer Peter Morrison, , from Rothesay, said he was called out to carry out a shoreline search at .am. Opposite the house where the youngster had been staying, he found what looked like a kitchen kne, jurors were told.Mr Morrison said he did not touch the kne, which he believed had been in the sea and left onshore by the receding tide. But he noted its location before continuing to search for Alesha. He later told police, who cordoned off the area, it was said. The teenager accused over Aleshas death denies abducting her, raping and murdering her, and attempting to hide evidence. He has lodged a special defence blaming Toni McLachlan - the girlfriend of Aleshas father, Robert MacPhail - for the killing.On Wednesday, Ms McLachlan told jurors she loved Alesha and had nothing to do with her death. The trial, before judge Lord Matthews, continues.

title: baby boy taken parents 9
story: NewsBaby boy taken off parents for  months - even though they did nothing wrongLisa Dixon and Andrew Eccles say they have suffered a nightmare as they fought to clear their name and get their son Macauley backShareCommentsByJames Campbell:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news real-le-stories video parents-horror-social-services-take-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum and dad had their baby boy taken off them for nine months due to an unexplained leg injury - even though they did nothing wrong. Lisa Dixon and Andrew Eccles say they have endured a nightmare as they fought to get their son Macauley back from social services, amid fears they had deliberately broken his legs.It took nine months, a police interview, four civil court appearances and two independent doctor reports before they were cleared of any wrongdoing, reports Hull Live .They were finally able to be reunited with Macauley just before Christmas. Miss Dixon has spoken of the stress and misery caused by the whole experience.   She said: “What happened nearly tore me and Andrew apart. It was even worse for Andrew because he could not see his eight-year-old daughter either. “It has been absolutely horrendous - really, really hard. I was in care myself so I am familiar with social services but this was still a big shock. “They just whipped our son away and it felt like they were pointing the finger. “I knew we had done nothing wrong but I started to question myself. I wonderedI had somehow raised his legs too high when changing his nappy or somehow handled him too roughly. “I lost my job and my partner almost lost his as well due to the time off we needed.” The terrible chain of events began in April  when Miss Dixon noticed something was wrong with Macauley. Miss Dixon, from Hull, said: “I noticed my son could not straighten his leg so we took him to a medical centre and then toHull Royal Infirmary.   “They took some X-Rays and they eventually found a fracture in one of his legs. As it was an unexplained injury the police and social services were called. “We believed the injury was caused by an exposed metal bar in the travel cot. “But doctors felt a lot of force must have caused the injury and felt we could have caused it deliberately. “They put my son through living hell with endless blood tests every day.” A couple of days later, social services decided to take Macauley away and he was sent to live with Miss Dixon’s mum, but neither Miss Dixon or Mr Eccles could see him. It was later discovered there was a fracture in his other leg too.   Miss Dixon said: “We did everything we could to prove we did not injure our own child. “We managed to get two independent doctors to say the injuries could have been inflicted by the travel cot. “Doctors discovered Macauley had afracture in his other legas well. It was odd because there was no swelling or bruising.” Miss Dixon accepts no chances can be taken with unexplained injuries among children but felt the way she and her partner were treated was unreasonable. She said: “We felt we were doing the right thing by taking him to hospital but it felt like we were being punished. “I understand social services have to act in situations like this but there just seemed to be a lot of finger pointing and it made us feeling like terrible parents. “Macauley is now also terried of going to the doctors after his experience. He has developed some kind of phobia.” Despite being a family once more, recovering from the experience has been a slow process. Miss Dixon said: “We are slowly piecing our lives back together but it has been hard. “My son has been with my mum for nine months so we are having to try and bond all over again.   Social services still come round to check on us but we are getting there. It is only now we are starting toto some kind of normality. I just want others to read this and and know you thatyou are innocent then you should not give up.” ButHull City Council, which runs social services in the city, says the priority is always the child in such circumstances. A spokesman said: “As a local authority we put the welfare of every child at the heart of what we do, and decisions like this are never taken lightly. “We work closely with our partners across the board to effectively identy children who are most at risk, so we can protect the city’s most vulnerable children.” The family are now also considering taking action against the manufacturer of the travel cot.

title: benefits cash could saved lives
story: NewsopinionBenefits cash could have saved the lives of Angela Smith - and thousands moreDonald Smiths daughter Angela took her own le believing her payments were being reassessed - then her dad received a cheque from the DWP for benefits underpaid to Angela of £.ShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  FEB NewsopinionAngela – a gentle soul who had suffered since childhood with severe mental health problems "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAngela Smith, a gentle soul who loved birds and nature, took her own le in  believing her disability benefits were being reassessed. She was already struggling to survive on the money she received due to a letime of severe mental health problems. This week, three years after his daughter’s suicide, Angela’s father, -year-old Donald Smith, received a cheque from the DWP for pound.. A letter said that Angela had, in fact, been underpaid by around pound a month from  to . Donald, now , says the money – around pound a month – “for Angela could have been the dference between le and death.” He adds that fears about money were “one of the principal reasons Angela took her own le.” The DWP says Angela was underpaid due to an “administrative error”.  The betrayal of Angela comes as the Labour Party launch a hard-hitting party political broadcast blaming a shameful , deaths on Tory austerity. The film, aired for the first time on Wednesday evening, says Tory cuts and NHS privatisation have caused a “national emergency”. The film explicitly links pound billion of cuts to health and social care and falling le expectancy and excess deaths in England. Donald first wrote to me in November , then aged . A heart-breaking letter enclosing the order of service from his daughter’s funeral. His beloved Angela, he said, had taken her own le after being told she faced a benefit reassessment, and having local psychiatric support withdrawn.   He has always blamed the DWP and austerity for Angela’s death. He also blames multiple failings by the now notorious Southern Health NHS Trust. At the time of her death, Angela’s case was even raised in Parliament by Luciana Berger MP, then shadow minister for Mental Health. “Do these people, the government ministers like Iain Duncan Smith, the pen pushers and bean counters, realise the misery and even death they are causing ” Donald says now. “Do they even care  I doubt it. It’s a lousy system that needs scrapping.” Donald’s comments come as a DWP minister, Sarah Newton claimed it is ‘shameful’ to claim benefit cuts have driven people to suicide. Sarah Newton accused critics of “deliberately misusing data” to say Tory welfare reforms are driving people to death. Meanwhile, James Cleverly, Deputy Chair of the Conservative Party, called the Labour broadcast “shameful scaremongering”. “They’re still at it now,” Donald says, talking about grandfather Jeff Hayward who this week won his appeal against being found fit for work – seven months after his death.  Mr Haywood had died in June after spending the last  months of his le battling for disability benefits. His family say the stress of his appeal and financial problems caused contributed to his death from a heart attack at the age of . Angela had been on the disability benefit ESA since August , but faced reassessment – which used to happen every two years – in . Before she died, she had spoken to her dad about friends facing similar problems who had recently taken their own lives. “This is the way they are trying to get rid of us, Dad, and for everyone that takes this way out, they probably open another bottle of champagne’,” she told Donald. Donald, a former factory worker, had spoken to his daughter on the Sunday before she died, and only realised later that she hadn’t ended the phone call with her usual “I love you, Dad”.  Now he says: “A more glaring example of how the benefits system’s gross inadequacies and mismanagement can impact profoundly on people with mental disabilities would be hard to find. To say it’s ironic, hardly covers it.” The Work Capability Assessment – or fit-for-work test – he says, “is long overdue to be scrapped”. The DWP says: “We want to ensure people receive the support they are entitled to and apologise for the error which resulted in Miss Smith receiving less in ESA support then she should have. We have paid full arrears to her family.” Meanwhile, partly because of cases like Angela’s ESA and Universal Credit Work Capability Assessments are no longer given to disabled people with the most severe and lelong conditions. Adding to her distress, Angela had recently been told she was no longer eligible to access mental health services she relied on, provided by Southern Health.  That is the same Trust linked to deaths including that of -year-old Connor Sparrowhawk, who drowned in the bath at a residential unit in their care in . Donald had been to her GP to beg for help, warning his daughter was suicidal, but to no avail. Donald is still unhappy with Southern Health’s report into Angela’s death, and the Trust remains in dialogue with him. Over three years since we first spoke, Donald has also lost his beloved we, and at  and in ill health himself, is still battling for answers. Knowing another , people have lost their lives to Tory austerity cuts responsible for brutal welfare reforms and decimated services, brings him no comfort.

title: dr pimple popper saves day
story: NewsDr Pimple Popper saves the day for bride-to-be with RHINO HORN growing from headWARNING: GRAPHIC CONTENT Dr Sandra Lee pulled the horn away from Lisas head after it grew for more than a yearShareCommentsByKelly-Ann Mills:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news weird-news video watch-dr-pimple-popper-deal-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, offlineSupport :, combinedPrompt :true, scope :  news uk-news  , theme : # , title : Mirror UK News ,bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mother who had a rhino horn growing out the back of her head for more than a year had the growth removed by Dr Pimple Popper. Lisa, , was forced to put her wedding plans on hold after feeling gross about the bizarre growth. She turned to celebrity surgeon Dr Sandra Lee - known to many as Dr Pimple Popper from her hit TV show - after she admitted the horn was causing her pain. Resembling a pork scratching, the hard, horn-like growth protruded out of the back of Lisa’s head, forcing her to hide it by tying her hair up into a bun.   Speaking before the procedure, a tearful Lisa said: It grows every day. It’s painful at times. It has a ring that it grows out of that is very tender. It’s a horn, basically. Like a rhinoceros - it’s a hard horn. I don’t want anybody to see it, so I wear my hair up and pretty much tuck it under my hair.” Although it causes Lisa pain, she said the emotional impact it is having is much worse. She added: The growth makes me feel gross. Who has, like, a horn growing out of their head ”  Lisa was so embarrassed by her horn, that she even put her wedding plans on hold because of it. I have been engaged to my fianceacute for five years. He’s been asking ‘oh, when are we going to set a date ’ and I put it off, because I want to look pretty on my wedding day. Usually when you get married you’re standing with your back to them. It [the horn] is the first thing I think they’re going to see.” Lisa, who was worried the growth was some kind of cancer, broke down during her consultation with Dr Lee.   But she was quickly put at ease, when she diagnoses the cutaneous horn, which is a projection from the skin made of compact white blood cells. Dr Lee said: “I’ve seen cutaneous horns before but certainly this is the largest cutaneous horn that I have ever seen.” After getting Lisa into her surgery and numbing the area, Dr Lee wrestled with the horn before pulling it free of Lisa’s head once and for all. Dr Pimple Popper airs Thursdays at pm on TLC

title: man faces losing home home
story: NewsMan faces losing his home after council mistakenly sells £k flat at half priceAntony Zomparelli, , says he was stunned when Islington Borough Council wrote to him admitting they had accidentally undercharged himShareCommentsByJack Longstaff:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsAntony Zomparelli is being taken to court by Islington Borough Council after they mistakenly sold him a flat at a low price "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA homeowner has been told to pay pound, or face losing his home - after the council wrongly sold him a pound, flat at half price. Dad Antony Zomparelli, , bought his two-bed flat from Islington Borough Council for pound, in . But he was stunned two years later when the council wrote to him admitting they had accidentally undercharged him - as they thought the home only had one bedroom. Security guard Antony, who has four children, could not afford to pay the dference - and now the council is taking him to court. The local authority wants to reclaim ownership of his flat or the money they claim he owes.   Single Antony, who lives in the second floor flat alone, says the unforgivable mistake has ruled his le ever since and is preparing for a court room fight later this year. He claims hed never have bought the houseit was on the market for pound, - and thinks the council have no right to DOUBLE the price over a sqm room. He said: I would never have bought the propertyI knew it was going to cost pound,. It would never have crossed my mind. How can they expect me to afford to pay. It has ruined my le. I cantas a normal person or think straight. It has caused me depression and Ive had to go to the doctors.   It has put a massive strain on my relationship with friends and family. Ive been in la la land since I got the first letter. I just couldnt believe it. I cant understand how they can do this, it seems impossible. Theyve clearly made a massive mistake and its of no fault of my own. Antony has lived in the flat, in Chadwell Street, Islington, since , and originally rented it from the council. He bought it from the authority under the Right To Buy scheme in , and because hed lived there for so long he got an pound, discount. The council priced it at pound, in August  and he got a pound, mortgage - for the remaining amount after the discount - in .  He was previously paying pound a week in rent but now pays around pound, a month in mortgage repayments. But two years later, in , Antony received a shocking letter from the council explaining the blunder, and demanding the remaining pound,. The council admitted it valued the home as a one-bed in a desktop valuation - a way of valuing a property or business using existing information. In legal documents, Antony - via solicitor Peter Felton of Feltons Law - alleges it was due to an error in the councils computerised records.  But Antony claims before the sale took place, an independent surveyor conducted a site survey of the flat. The bedroom in question is a box room and Antony claims it was mentioned on his lease, drawn up by the council. The council is claiming security guard, Antony, has been unjustly enriched by the apparent admin blunder. In a letter to Antony in March , the council explained where a public body acts outside their jurisdiction, their decision is void. The letter included the councils admission that it had no power to dispose of the premises at a lower valuation than that based on market value.  As a result, the council is entitled to recover the funds, by way of restitution for unjust enrichment, the letter said. Lawyers acting on behalf of the council tried to settle outside of court and offered Antony the option to agree terms for restoration of the balance of the purchase price. But the two parties failed to agree terms, and in a letter sent to Antony in October , he was issued an ultimatum - either accept liability to pay up, or enter a legal battle. Court papers prepared for proceedings say the council has a duty to recover the missing pound,, as they acted outside their statutory powers by granting the lease at an undervalue.  In a letter, sent in October , the council offered Antony a final  day window in which to settle the dispute outside of legal proceedings, and warned of lodging a claim against himhe still refused to pay. Both parties have prepared court papers but a start date for proceedings is yet to be confirmed. Worried Antony said: Up until  everything was completely fine. I first heard about all of this when the council sent me a pretty aggressive letter. It even said we understand this letter may cause you some distress. They told me by letter my property had been undervalued and we need to resolve the pound, I now owe them. Even my barrister has said he has no idea what the outcome will be.  I have no idea how they can justy asking for that much more money. It has always been a two-bed flat. It was never a one-bed. Its madness really. They have doubled the price of a property based on a box room. Antony says he is the victim of an admin error and is being punished for something out of his control. The council and Antony are due to begin legal proceedings at Clerkenwell and Shoreditch County Court but are awaiting confirmation on a date. Antony has enlisted the help of solicitors for the upcoming legal battle and says he is adamant hell keep his home. Antonys defence barrister, Christopher Royal QC, claims there is no reported case of a former landlord claiming damages from the former tenant due to an undervaluation. But the homeowner fears evenhe wins in court, hell have to sell his flat to pay for the legal bill - which he fears could top pound,. He said: No matter what happens I will have to sell the property to pay my legal fees. If I win Ill get the fee back for my barrister but Ill have to pay some costs for my solicitor and mortgage company. I will probably be unable to live in London anymore. Ill be bankruptI lose. Antony says he took the decision to buy the flat for the benefit of his children and wanted to ensure he leaves a legacy for them in London. He said: I wasnt surprised at the price when I bought it. It was the first time Id ever bought a property so it seemed a lot of money to me. I wanted to get on the property ladder for my children and I was really happy.  I wanted to make my childrens lives easier for when they want a home. I thought it was odd how they valued it on a computer but I was ensured it was normal. The effect on me has been incredible. It has ruled my le for four year. I dont wish I never bought it in the first place. I got a lot of fulfilment from it. The most unjust part of it is I will still lose the property evenI win. I cant get my head around it, evenI win I know Ill still be losing.has contacted Islington Borough Council for comment.

title: mystery sad dog abandoned beach
story: NewsMystery of sad dog abandoned on beach with Valentines Day balloon solvedOne visitor to Langland Bay in Swansea said it looked like "a Disney movie, with a lonely prince trying to find his princess"ShareCommentsByLaura ClementsAmber Hicks:,  FEB NewsConcerned beach visitors snapped a picture of the pooch "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The mystery surrounding a dog found abandoned on a beach with an I love you balloon tried to him has been solved. Fears had been raised by walkers over the sad pooch after they spotted him alone on Langland Bay in Swansea on Valentines Day.It was a scene that couldnt fail to melt even the hardest of hearts, especially when the lovelorn figure got up and strolled towards the rocks, trailing his balloon sadly behind him.Some passersby believed he may have been stood up by his Valentines date - others feared something more sinister may have happened to his owner, reports Wales Online .  However, it has now emerged the dog is an English Pointer named Gordon - born in Turkey and adopted by a family in Wales.He is in fact a local celebrity who has his own Facebook page named Gordons Tails My Le in Wales ,Gordon, who has cancer, is spending his final days showered with love by his Welsh family, who rescued him after he had spent almost all his le abused or in a shelter home. And he couldnt fail to catch the attention of visitors to the beach yesterday as he ran in the sand with the Valentines balloon flying behind him. Joann Randles, who was on the beach with her partner for a late-afternoon walk, took his photo as he wandered up and down the beach.   We started off in Caswell Bay and walked over to Langland, where there happened to be a dog with a balloon tied to its collar all on its own, she said. We didnt think anything of it, but he looked so sad, I took his picture. The couple continued to walk across the bay, and as they walked back, the dog was still there. Miss Randles added: There were other dogs on the beach with their owners, and he went over to seemingly try and play with them, but they all ran off. That was when we realised he didnt seem to have anyone with him, like an owner or anything.   It looked like a Disney movie, with a lonely prince trying to find his princess. The dog hung around on the beach until Miss Randle left just before pm. But for the rest of the evening, she couldnt help wonderinghe ever did find someone who loved him. It was cute at the time, but it played on my mind when I got home, said the -year-old. Where were his owners  He looked so forlorn with his droopy face, and it being Valentines Day, it seemed ironic. I cant help wonderinghe did ever find a date or a friend. Gordons owners confirmed he was perfectly happy - although a bit mfed off he had to wear a balloon.   Writing on behalf on Gordon, Jayne Lambe posted on the poochs Facebook page: So today is Valentines Day,a day to spoil and cherish your loved one. And what do I get...faggots  HD  Steak  No of course not I get a f***ing stupid balloon attached to me and made to go out in public! Not content to strapping a helium balloon to me in a gale force wind she proceeds to video the shame! And she calls this love! Thankfully there is now HD in the freezer and Im making sure I get it as Ive bloody well earned it today! I could have ended up in Devonthe wind had changed. Have a fab Valentines everyone andyou get a helium balloon ....I sympathise!

title: obese woman who always skipped
story: NewsObese woman who always skipped PE to avoid changing in public sheds  STONEJessica Seals diet consisted of FIVE fizzy drinks, fast food and chocolate every single dayShareCommentsByRebecca Drew:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsJessicas diet would be based on fast food and chocolate "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A woman who used to be so horried by her own obesity that she would refuse to change for PE classes has shed an impressive seven stones in just two years.Commissioning development lead for the NHS, Jessica Seal, , would binge on chocolate and use food as her escape while she was being brought up by her dad who struggled with mental health. With her mum working nights, Jessicas older sisters, Laura and Rebecca, who were only  and  at the time, would look after her so it was all Iceland oven and microwave food. She had a sweet tooth and would crave anything sweet which would see her drink two cans of regular coke, three cans of diet coke and a chocolate bar each evening.  But she equally used to hate the way she looked and while she would dream of going shopping in Topshop with her friends as Dorothy Perkins was the only shop catering for her size. Since starting to learn about health aged , Jessica has shed a staggering seven stone and now fits a size  . She hopes to inspire others with her transformation and prove that you dont need to join a slimming club, spend money on expensive meal plans or a personal trainer to lose weight.  I was uneducated on nutrition and healthy eating and I was inactive as a child due to being overweight. At school I never did a lesson of PE because the thought of getting changed in a public place was horric - never mind actually getting on a trampoline. I used to get into a lot of trouble in secondary school with fights and being disruptive because I didnt have any confidence within myself and this was how I got accepted - only now I can look back and realise thats how I felt although on the surface I wouldnt have seemed bothered about my weight at all.  But it wasnt until after her sister, Rebecca, was diagnosed with gestational diabetes whilst she was pregnant in , at st lb and a UK size  to , that Jessica - who had a BMI of  - decided to actually do something. Through my work I started to see the risks around obesity and awareness around eating healthy. I saw a picture of myself and the mayor of Lewisham that was taken in front of a theatre full of people when I completed my level three apprenticeship. When I saw it, I thought is that what I really look like, I couldnt look at the picture because it made me feel so insecure and embarrassed. Jessica joined a spin class in March  and eventually plucked up the courage to join her local gym where she started going twice a week.  She educated herself on nutrition and started to prepare healthy meals for herself at the start of each week. Now, Jessica is a super svelte size eight to  and st lb and feels more confident than she ever has before. Before her weight loss Jessica would skip breakfast altogether, have a lunch of McDonalds, KFC, a meal deal from Tesco or a sandwich from Subway. Her dinner would consist of large portions of pre-prepared meals such as sausages, chips and bread or pizza. In between meals, Jessica would snack on anything sweet like biscuits, cakes or chocolate. Now Jessica always makes time for breakfast which is rice cakes and fruit when she is on the go or poached eggs on brown toastshes at home. For lunch she has chicken, rice and steamed vegetables or a homemade hotpot or salad.  For dinner she has something similar or an oven baked salmon fillet.Since her transformation, Jessica likes to keep herself busy whereas before she was happy to sit in front of the telly in the evening. She has also shared her weight loss journey to her Instagram profile.Losing weight has made me much more aware of my health and how important it is to look after your body. Health is wealth, she said. I have a lot more energy I find myself wanting to keep active and busy whereas before I was content with a pizza, bottle of coke and the TV.  I feel much more confident, it has allowed me to think hard work does pay off and you can really achieve anythingyou put your mind to it. I want to inspire others with my story. I never thought it was possible to achieve weight loss without signing up to a slimming club, buying meal replacements or a personal trainer. People dont always recognise Jessica when shes out and about because she looks so dferent from how she did before, but she says her friends and family have supported her throughout her lestyle change. A lot of people dont recognise me, I have had to give people my full name before they realise who it is. My close friends and family are proud, they have supported and embraced my new-found love for fitness and even my step-dad has lost just over two stone recently, she said. Surround yourself with those who inspire you. If you never try, youll never know and it all starts from within and taking that first step to make a change, like I did with parking my car further and going to a spin class.For more information see www.instagram jj.workingonabetterme

title: popular schoolgirl looking down phone
story: NewsPopular schoolgirl was looking down at phone before she was killed by trainEvie Wright, , was found lying face down across the railway tracks at Corondale Crossing in Worle, SomersetShareCommentsBySarah Lumley:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsEvie Wright, , a high-achieving pupil who excelled at sports and loved le "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA happy and popular schoolgirl was killed by a train as she walked across a level crossing looking at her phone, an inquest heard. Evie Wright, , was seen by a child witness looking down at her phone, like she was checking the time just before she was struck. I instinctively closed my eyes, and when I opened them about ten seconds later, I could see her lying face down on the track, and the train was stopped, the witness told. Evie, a high-achieving pupil, was found lying face down across the railway tracks at Corondale Crossing in Worle, Somerset on March , , after being hit by a train at mph. Her devastated mother said Evie loved le, adding that there was always music in the house and that her daughter was always singing and dancing.  The teen had gone to school as normal then ed home where she sent a message to a friend with a picture of a dress she was going to wear to a sleepover. She seemed happy and went out again and started tohome when she opened a gate and walked across a railway pedestrian crossing. The hearing was told a child witness saw Evie with her head down and was looking at her phone just before she opened the gate. Evie kept looking down at her phone, like she was checking the time and was struck by the train, the witness said. A pedestrian bridge was supposed to have been built at the site  years ago, yesterdays inquest heard. Her father Lee Wright demanded at the inquest that a footbridge is installed. A coroner said she could find no evidence that Evie intended to harm herself or take her own le and says she will write to the council to ask the same. Mr Wright told the inquest: This has been going on since ,  years before my daughter was born,  years before she died. Whilst all this is going on in the background, children are trying to cross this crossing. Our daughter is not the first to die like this. I am disappointed in the people responsible for this, and I would like to request something is done as soon as possible.  In a statement, one of her teachers, Mandy Smith, said Evie had left halfway through a school trampolining lesson crying on the day. The P.E. teacher said: One of her friends askedshe could go and make sure Evie was alright. Five minutes later, they were both back in the lesson behaving normally. Evie seemed okay, she didnt look like shed been crying. I went and stood next to her and askedshe was alright, but she didnt answer. I then went to correct the leg position of another pupil on the trampoline, and I turned back to Evie to see her leave the gym again. A few minutes later, she came back in. She didnt seem upset, just a bit quiet. After the lesson, I asked Evie to get changed and come up to the office. I asked againshe was alright, and she said nothing in reply. She didnt say much at all but she made good eye contact. She didnt appear upset, and we parted as my next class came in. Detective Inspector Paul Stanley, of British Transport Police, said Evie had been involved in a falling out at school on the day she died, which had upset her. He said: At the end of the school day on Tuesday, Evie sometimes attended netball practice - but on this day she did not. Evie left school around . hours with a friend, and it is believed that she went straight home. At ., Evie Snapchatted a friend to show a picture of the outfit she intended to wear to a sleepover that she was excited for. Evie was in her bedroom at this time, and the outfit in the Snapchat was not the outfit Evie was wearing when she was killed, meaning she must have changed after sending the Snapchat. Between . and ., Evie had a conversation on social media with her friend about normal things, and she seemed happy. Shortly after, she left the house. It is not known where she went - but from the direction she was approaching the crossing when she was killed, it seems she was headed in the direction of home.  A child witness, who was also waiting at the crossing, said Evie had her head down and was looking at her phone just before she opened the gate at the side of the crossing. The witness, who did not know Evie, said: The train was quite far away, past the bridge, but I could see it getting bigger as it approached, so I stopped and waited. The girl kept looking down at her phone, like she was checking the time. I heard a loud crash as the gate opened and closed behind her, and she looked to be moving vigorously across the track. She was on the track looking at her phone, and then she leaned forward asto see the train. I instinctively closed my eyes, and when I opened them about ten seconds later, I could see her lying face down on the track, and the train was stopped. Simon Harkus, who was driving the Great Western Railway train, claimed in a statement that he saw Evie looking up at the train seconds before it hit her. He said: I was travelling at approximately -mph as I approached the foot crossing, and as I drew close to the crossing, I saw a young girl waiting on the right side. I saw her looking up at me as she stepped towards the crossing. There was nothing I could do to stop my train at such a short distance. I saw the girl hunch down as though bracing herself, and then I felt the impact as the train hit her. Avon Coroners Court heard North Somerset Council granted planning permission in  to build a footbridge over the line, less than m from where Evie was killed. Network Rail Operations Risk Advisor, Simon Aston, said Network Rail and the council have been locked in discussions ever since. The Councils Service Manager, Roger Willmot, said planning permission was first granted in , after the council initially accepted the proposal in . Mr Willmott said: Planning permission was submitted by a consortium of developers, and in  permission was granted, stating that the building of a footbridge was an obligation.  However, with the privatisation and split of British Rail into three separate companies in , and the bankruptcy of the original developers, the plans went into a recessionary period, the inquest was told. Mr Aston said that discussions about the footbridge opened up once more in , and that Network Rail is currently designing a bridge to comply with new Network Rail requirements. But he added: Network Rail fully supports the construction of a bridge, but it is not our responsibility to provide it. The obligation is on the developers to build the footbridge. Mr Willmott, of North Somerset Council, said: We continue to press ahead with trying to maintain the dialogue with Network Rail and a new developer. We will continue to pursue that. In a family statement, prepared by Evies mother, Natasha Deakin, Evie was described as a happy girl with a wide circle of friends. Natasha said: She was described by her friends as the kindest, most genuine friend, always there for a hug. On the whole she loved le - there was always music in the house, she was always singing and dancing, and she spent a lot of time talking to friends on social media. She was a confident girl with a rational and empathetic nature. She was very generous to friends and would often stick up for them. A deep sadness is felt throughout Evies family and friends at the loss of our beautul daughter, and will remain for a very long time. Senior Coroner Maria Voisin, at Avon Coroners Court, recorded a narrative conclusion at Evies inquest. She said she will be writing to North Somerset Council and development company Persimmon Homes to recommend the building of a footbridge. She said: I simply do not know why Evie did what she did on March , . I cannot find any evidence that Evie intended to harm herself or take her own le. I record a narrative conclusion, the details of which are that Evie died from multiple injuries when she was struck by a train. On March , , she walked onto a railway line and into the path of a train, which struck her. Her intentions when she walked onto the train line are unknown. All that is left for me to say to her family is how very sorry I am.

story: NewsSerial love rat who infected gran, , with HIV jailed over new relationshipJames Defalco was sentenced to  months after breaching court orders which meant he must disclose to any woman he meets that he is HIV positiveShareByNick IrvingAbigail OLeary:,  FEB NewsJames Defalco was sentenced to  months after breaching court orders "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA HIV-positive serial love rat who infected an -year-old grandmother with the virus has been jailed for his relationship with another woman. James Defalco was sentenced to  months after breaching court orders which meant he must tell any woman he meets that he is HIV positive. The order was first made in  when he infected an -year-old woman with the virus after having sex with her. Since then Defalco has breached the Sexual Offences Prevention Orderand Sexual Harm Prevention Orderon ious occasions. Those orders banned him for engaging in sex with anyonehe had not told them he was HIV positive, and associating with children under  in a public or private place. Yesterday Judge Paul Cook jailed him for a total of  months. Defalco met his latest victim after setting up a profile on the dating website Plenty of Fish. He told his victim she looked lovely and he met the woman and visited her and her family on four occasions.   Judge Paul Cook said: You engaged in sexual activity with her which involved intimate kissing. The sexual activity was intimate but it fell short of penile penetration. The judge said he also played with her two-year-old great granddaughter, bouncing her up and down on his knees and playing with her toys. He said he infected the -year-old woman with HIV when he was  and in  he had a sexual relationship with a -year-old woman. Prosecutor Mary McCarthy said Defalco has a long history of offending including violence, dishonesty and sexual offences. In  he breached the orders four times when he undertook work for an elderly lady. In  after he was freed from jail he associated with a vulnerable female family member. In  he breached it by going to Guernsey with a woman with whom he had unprotected sex. And again in  he befriended a woman who had children. Exeter Crown Court said his police offender manager investigated last September that Defalco had begun a relationship with a -year-old woman in Brixham, Devon.   Miss McCarthy said: It quickly developed into a relationship but not a sexual one. They were close quite quickly and there was kissing and sexual touching. She had not been informed he was HIV positive. Defalco was arrested but told police he had informed the woman of his HIV status. And he said their relationship was a friendly one where he pecked her on the cheek - and denied it was a sexual relationship. Kevin Hopper, defending, said: There is a theme here of the same old offences committed time and time again. The terms of the order have been made crystal clear to him. He said Defalco, of Brixham, Devon, claims the chances of passing on his viral infection are zero. Mr Hopper said: He does not consider himself a sex offender. The order is an albatross around his neck. He said-year-old Defalco discloses his sexual status to anyone it marks the end of the relationship before it has started. Defalco admitted breaching the SOPO in October  and breaching the SHPO in January . The judge told him: You have persistently breached the order since . The public are entitled to protection because you have infected someone in the past. He said Defalco had retreated from the last relationship just as police began investigating him.

title: ex nurse kim kardashian style
story: NewsEx nurse has Kim Kardashian-style bum lt treatment to help agonising conditionAmy Daniels suffers from scleroderma, which causes her own body to attack itselfShareCommentsByHannah StevensJane Lavender:,  FEB News "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An ex-nurse has opted to have a bum lt inspired by Kim Kardashian in a last ditch attempt to each her rare and agonising condition. Amy Daniels suffers from the chronic autoimmune disorder scleroderma, which causes her body to attack itself.And she hopes the drastic surgery, loved by reality TV stars, will help relieve her pain. The -year-old was diagnosed in  and her condition means her immune system attacks connective tissues around blood vessels and internal organ and causes scarring. Amy, from Wisconsin in the US, had a stem cell transplant which worked until .   By December , willing to give anything a try, she had liposuction to drain fat from her abdomen, before it was injected back into her hands, feet and around her mouth, in a bid to help with circulation. Amy said: “I have a pretty high pain threshold but the fat transfer, which is also known as fat grafting, hurt. “I look at all these reality stars and can’t imagine how much pain those chicks are in all the time just to look good, while I’m doing it to feel better.” Amy, who has two children, Martha, , and Lucy, , with her motorcycle designer husband Mark, , first experienced symptoms of scleroderma shortly after giving birth to her youngest daughter in . Initially assuming her hands had swollen because of water retention during breastfeeding, she realised it was something more when they became so sensitive that even simple tasks, like switching on a light and grabbing a pen, were agony.   By the summer of  her hands also started turning purple and she developed pitting – a type of scarring common in scleroderma patients – on her fingertips. Medics tol her to monitor her symptoms and speak to a rheumatologistthey persisted. She only started thinking she could have scleroderma after a chance comment from a neighbour. Amy said: One day, completely out of the blue in October , a neighbour said, ‘Wow, you’re so tanned.’ “As a nurse, I’d looked after one patient with scleroderma, who had hyperpigmented skin that looked like a super dark tan. “My husband remembers me saying at the time thatthere was any disease I didn’t want to get, it was scleroderma.  “But, after my neighbour made that comment, it put that word, scleroderma, in my head for the first time. The next day I looked it up and there were all my symptoms. I knew right then and my heart sank. “I was terried that I’d die and not see my kids grow up.” Seeking an immediate referral to a rheumatologist, who she met with the following month, her diagnosis was confirmed. Scleroderma is catergorised into two main types - localised, which just affects the skin, and systemic, which Amy has, and also impacts on the blood circulation and internal organs. She was also found to have Raynaud’s syndrome, which affects the blood vessels in the fingers, particularly when it is cold.  Sadly, many people with scleroderma also have Raynauds, according to the charity Scleroderma and Raynaud’s UK , which is supporting February’s Raynaud’s Awareness Month, inviting those who may be affected to seek advice. Amy said: “I’ll never forget hearing the news in the dingy basement of this office building. I just started sobbing “I was warned that it was very severe, and was affecting my lungs as it was hardening the vessels inside the organ. “The doctor even said it might be an idea to get my affairs in order. It was awful.” After her initial shock Amy found a more specialist doctor who had experience treating scleroderma. She had her stem cell transplant in  as the treatment was still being trialled.  To prepare her for the procedure she endured aggressive chemotherapy to wipe her immune system before she received the new stem cells. Amy said: “I was in the first handful of patients to undergo a stem cell transplant for scleroderma.” After the procedure, to ensure her immune system was not compromised, Amy was more or less “housebound” until she grew stronger. But the treatment was a huge success until . She was out of remission and the painful ulcers, commonly found on the digits of scleroderma patients, ed with a vengeance. At their most severe, Amy said they could last for more than a year and be prone to infection.  As her feet were affected husband Mark made her special flip flops, as wearing normal shoes was too painful. Then, desperate for some relief, her interest was piqued when she heard about fat grafting through a doctor friend, which she tried in December . Known as autologous lipotransfer, the procedure, which is also used as a reconstruction technique in breast cancer patients, sees fat harvested and enriched with the patient’s own stem cells, before being reinjected. It is hoped this will mean facial tissue can be reconstructed and the thickening and scarring of connective tissue that comes with scleroderma will be reversed. Amy said: “Scleroderma has given me a lot of lines, particularly around my mouth. It takes your looks from you, but I’m so past caring about that.  “You almost go through a death of your old self and a rebirth of this new person. “The fat transfer treatment wasn’t about my looks, but it can also help with skin stretching which I did care about. The hope is that it aids the healing of any wounds you have, and gives you a little more padding for your circulation.” As well as the fat graft, Amy had Botox injected into the rest of her extremities as a temporary measure before getting fat transfers in those areas also in the future. Now she appears to be doing well but still feels asshe is playing a waiting game to seethe fat transfer has worked for her. She is also waiting to start a course of physical therapy to her hand, to help improve her strength.  Amy said: “Scleroderma is an invisible illness, so when you look fine and normal, people take it that you are. As the years go on, they stop asking how you’re feeling because they don’t want to know. “Still, I try to focus on the positives and give my body kudos every day for going through what it has. “Very early on, I realised I couldn’t be staying in bed feeling sorry for myself. If I die early, I want my kids to see that I had this heinous disease and fought my butt off to give them as normal a le as possible. “In , they give me strength to get up in the morning and I am very grateful for that.” For information, visit www.sruk

title: woman shares devastating 10 month
story: NewsWoman shares devastating -month challenge of sister - ending at her funeralWARNING: UPSETTING IMAGES - Sister Chrystal Charlesworth posted the pictures of her little charismatic sibling to raise awarenessShareCommentsByClaire Gilbody-Dickerson:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsLexus lay in the same exact church room as her nana "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA distraught sibling has shared pictures of her -year-old opium-addicted sister posing beside her nanas coffin before lying in her own casket ten months later.In a hair-raising post on Facebook, bereaved Chrystal Charlesworth, from Gettysburg, Pennsylvania, shared the two pictures of her younger sister Lexus Felton, who died of overdose just as they thought she had got clean.Chrystal posted one picture from March  where her sister, dressed in a pink top, white trousers and heels, posed with her dead grandma, who lay in a coffin next to her. The second picture was dated December , and shows the same -year-old lying in the same exact church room, wearing the same exact shirt and laying in the same exact kind of casket my grandmother [was ] in.   year challenge  Let’s talk about a MONTH challenge, Chrystal wrote. Little did I know that when I took the first picture of my inappropriately hilarious, charismatic little sister that it would end up having such a surreal meaning behind it just a few short months later.. Chrystal explained how her sister had been sober at the time of her nanas funeral. But she then started doing heroine again for a little over a month, at which point their mother brought her to a probation officer for her to admit she had been using again.  She spent three months and a half in jail before a bed freed up at a rehab in Philadelphia. Lexus had done it all willingly as she wanted to stay clean, the sister said. Once in rehab, she spent three months getting clean and after a final shot of vivitrol, which aims to tackle the drug crave, she was finally sent back home. My sister would have only  full days left with us. On the th day she would die of a heroin overdose, Chrystal wrote. Out of those  days she only used for three of them. It only took THREE days of using again.. It only took one last hit for her body to go into cardiac arrest and ultimately cause her to take her last breath. My sister died somewhere between :AM-:AM. She was to be home at AM, just an hour later.  Claiming eight people die in the US of opioid overdose each hour, Chrystal said she posted the pictures to raise awareness about the addiction as a national crisis. I know I never thought I’d be someone who had to go through the reality of burying someone I love due to this issue.. And I hate that more people will have to going forward. Please, use my sister as an example. Use her story to fear taking that next hit or use it as motivation to confront your loved one about their addiction, the -year-old concluded.

story: NewsWoman horried after catching mother-in-law tampering with her birth controlA woman has shared her horror after catching her mother-in-law doing something shocking in her bedroomShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsA woman is in a horrible situation thanks to her mother-in-law"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWhen youve been with someone for a long time, its only natural your parents might start putting pressure on you to give them grandchildren. But whether or not you want to have children is a decision that is totally and completely up to you, your partner and no one . However one mum clearly didnt get this memo, as she decided to take matters into her own hands when her son and his we told her they didnt want to have a baby. She began by explaining that she and her husband are in their late s and had made a deliberate decision not to have children.Some people had labelled them selfish for choosing this, but the worst response came from the husbands mother who apparently went into hysterics and began raving about how the bloodline and family name will die. The couple remained true to their decision despite this and hoped she would come around eventually, but she never did - and now shes gone and done something despicable.   After offering to cook dinner for the couple one night, the mother-in-law sent her son out to the shops to buy some ingredients. His we explains how she ed home from work, to find her husband still out of the house. So she went upstairs to change, but what she saw upon entering her bedroom has turned her world upside down.Her mother-in-law was poking holes in the couples condoms.  She wrote: When I opened the door into our bedroom what I see is what looks like MIL carefully trying to poke holes into our condoms. She snaps her head in my direction with this mortying deer in the headlights look on her face. Like a fish out of water. She mumbles something about how shes trying to save the family and frantically runs out of the house before I even have a chance to say anything. When her husband eventually came home, she recounted the events to him and says he was absolutely horried by his mothers actions.  To make matters worse, they soon realised that she had been in the home a few weeks earlier and could have tampered with their contraception then as well. Reddit users were equally as horried to hear her story, with one person telling them to go to the police and press charges against the mum. Others said they should end all contact with her and described the behaviour as assault. Many advised that the couple chuck out all of their condoms immediately and take a pregnancy test, just in case the mother-in-law had been doing this for a while. Sadly it seemed she had done it before and after taking a test and visiting the doctor, the woman updated her post to reveal that she was in fact pregnant with her first child and is unsure of what to do next.Im so distraught that I havent been able to sleep in the last four days, she admitted. Im sorry I didnt update sooner but Ive been in a really dark place. At this point we havent even spoke or contacted MIL. Shes been blowing up our phones for the last three days, but we havent responded. Im just so lost as to what to do. I mean I never wanted to have kids sure, but at the same time having an abortion feels so wrong to me. She added: I cant believe Im in this situation right now. I dont know what Im going to do.

The animals refused to leave the one-year-old who was still alive and unable to get out of the deep pit. The tragic accident took place as the herd walked close to the village of Mahipani in north-western India on Wednesday night. In the dark, the animal slipped into the hole and the herd refused to give up on the baby and remained at the spot.   Concerned locals tried to drive them away over fears they would enter the village and used torches and firecrackers to try and get them to leave. One of the elephants threatened to run towards the mob while they started throwing stones at it. After a number of hours the herd finally gave up and walked back into the forest. The forest department arrived at the spot as soon as they received the information and tried to rescue the creature in distress.   But they could only recover the dead elephant calf from the pit the next morning. The villagers, out of sympathy observed last rites to the dead aninal. Forestry officials inspected the area to check for any more pits or gaps left open by the railway department to avoid further accidents.

title: hero grizzly saves mumma bear
story: NewsHero Grizzly saves mumma bear and cub after they were attacked by ,lb maleThe mother bear was saved by the brave bear who risked his own to save her and the cub at the Katmai National Park in AlaskaShareCommentsByMark McConvilleKelly-Ann Mills:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video hero-grizzly-saves-mum-cub-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA hero Grizzly bear raced to save a mother and her cub from being killed after they were attacked by a huge ,lb male. Amazingly clear footage captured the terrying encounter as the two bears faced each other down. The clip starts with a number of bears feeding on a huge whale carcass before the bully bear suddenly charges at the cub. The mum tries desperately to step in and save her young bear but she is no match for the bigger animal.   The brave male sees she is in trouble and races over to help, taking on the bear head to head. The thrilling video was captured in Katmai National Park, Alaska, USA, by naturalist guide for natural habitat adventures, Brad Josephs, from Yellville, Arkansas, USA. The -year-old said: There is no food on earth more attractive to bears than whale blubber, and the strong scent draws them in from many miles around. Blubber is what keeps marine mammals warm in cold water, and in whales it can be a foot thick. The lipid content and blood vessel concentration of blubber is much higher than other fatty tissues in nature, which makes it a better insulator for a living whale, and incredibly nutritious for scavenging bears.   A very complex and dynamic hierarchy quickly develops when multiple bears have found a whale carcass. These bears on the coast have evolved special social skills and what I call personal space flexibility. They can share concentrated food sources, like a salmon stream, with other bears, rather than spend too much energy in competition. We saw as many as four bears eating the whale at one time, and on several occasions, a wolf and a bear feeding together. Most of the bears were mellow and didnt mind sharing, but during the several days we spent there we saw several giant males - at least , pounds - who werent so tolerant.  When one of these big guys was eating, the younger bears and females had to sit out until he was full and fast asleep. When more than one big guy was hungry at the same time, they had to decide who the real carcass boss was. He added: The tensions were high, and a fight between them was imminent for sure. Instead, Bully attacks a blond female with a third summer cub. Bullys sheer size, and the proximity to the waters edge, made for a grave situation that I thought would be fatal for the mother bear. But out of nowhere, the competing male charges and fully engages with Bully. This male did in fact save the mother bear from a likely death, but who knows why he did it. Was he trying to be a hero  I think he saw an opportunity at gaining an upper hand on his competitor while he was distracted, but with an animal as complex as a grizzly bear, you cant know for sure, and thats what makes watching bears so amazing.

story: NewsMum, , has SEPTUPLETS in remarkable natural birth with six girls and one boyThe mum, who has not been named, is also in good health after the rare birth in the Diyali Province of eastern IraqShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsFather Youssef Fadl confirmed the septuplets are in perfect health after their check-ups "Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA new mother delivered a remarkable seven babies in a single natural birth with all the children reportedly in perfect condition and doing well. title: george cran dundee are in a far better place now than when jim mcintyre arrived
story: Almost four months into his reign as Dundee manager, Jim McIntyre won’t look back on his first match in charge with too much fondness.However, he might just do so with a great deal more satisfaction with how his squad has shaped up in the time since.Despite only picking up two wins and six draws in the  matches under McIntyre, there’s a growing sense of optimism at Dens Park after some encouraging displays since the January transfer window.The opposite can be said of Saturday’s opponents Livingston, the side the Dark Blues faced in Jim’s debut in the dugout.After a lightning-fast start to theirto the Premiership – which peaked with that - thumping of Dundee back in October – Livi’s form has slipped off a clf with last Wednesday’s - draw at Hearts bringing a five-game losing streak to an end.Since leaving Dundee gaffer Jim in no doubt how big a job he had on his hands with that - success at the Tony Macaroni Arena, Gary Holt’s side have only picked up three victories and none since the middle of December.That’s seen them slip from a high of second spot with  points from their first eight games down to ninth with just  picked up from the following  matches.And, though the gap between the sides hasn’t shrunk in those four months, the feeling around both clubs right now couldn’t be more dferent.A massive part of that from Dundee’s point of view is the complete overhaul of the playing squad in the winter transfer window.In fact, there’s a fair chance there won’t be any of the players who featured in the - defeat the last time the Dark Blues travelled to West Lothian this time around.Only three of the  used by Jim that day remain at the club – Elliott Parish, Cammy Kerr and Kenny Miller.Of those, only Miller looks like he could be given a start this time around but even he has a fair bit of competition to overcome with Andrew Nelson on the goal trail and Craig Curran preferred by the manager to lead the line in every match since he arrived at the club at the start of January.A missed penalty in stoppage time in their last run-out won’t have helped veteran Miller’s cause either.Meanwhile, Parish hasn’t featured since that - thumping and doesn’t look like dislodging Seny Dieng as first choice any time soon.The nature of the goals that day, with all four from set-pieces, no doubt led the manager to question his defenders.Parish quickly paid the price by dropping to the bench while three of the back four have been moved on.Andy Boyle is now at Ross County, Ryan Inniss was sent back to Crystal Palace after a nightmare at Palmerston in the Scottish Cup and Calvin Miller has also dropped to the Championship, being picked up by Ayr United on loan from Celtic.Kerr was right-back in October but he’s seen his place taken by new signing James Horsfield in recent games.The former Manchester City kid has looked assured in Kerr’s place and will take some shting before Saturday.The rest of the team have since been shown the exit door – Glen Kamara, Kharl Madianga, Lewis Spence, Sofien Moussa, Benjy Kallman, Roarie Deacon and Adil Nabi have all moved on.Even the side that drew - with Livi at Dens on Boxing Day will be unrecognisable to the one running out this weekend.Whatever side he opts for, Jim knows his team are in a far better place than when he took over – now they have to prove that by getting points on the board.

title: tom duthie this time the renewed hope at dundee united might not be a false dawn
story: For the first time in a long time, perhaps even since the dark days of relegation in , there is strong reason for optimism at Dundee United.The one thing that should be stressed about that immediately is it’s still early days.Robbie Neilson’s rebuilt team is only two games in and that means there is some way to go before we can confirm things are definitely on the up at Tannadice.And the truth is that will only come with promotion back to the Premiership.It must also be said there have been other  dawns over the past three years.The arrival of Ray McKinnon and then Csaba Laslo as managers brought hope and even early promise that, after the disastrous   campaign, things were being turned around.In fairness to McKinnon in particular, had he been handed the kind of budget that was made available to the current team boss in the January transfer window, the major problems at the club might well have been sorted and the Tangerines could have been back in the top flight already.Unfortunately for him, those in the boardroom when he was in charge were unable to provide the kind of cash for signings new American owner Mark Ogren has.That, incidentally, is not a criticism of the previous regimes, just an unfortunate fact.Neilson has been lucky he’s got an owner with dollars to spend and the indications so far suggest that owner is just as fortunate that he has a manager who knows how to spend it wisely.Ogren can also consider himself blessed his predecessor in the chairman’s seat at Tannadice, Mike Martin, found not just a good manager, but one who through being out of the game for a period, had taken the time to look at United and form a clear picture of what was needed.Because one thing that’s obvious about the signings made is all have been part of a jigsaw in the manager’s mind.January  didn’t just come round and see Neilson turn his thoughts to what was available. He’d done his homework and, equally importantly, worked out exactly where his squad needed strengthening.That means the right players for the right positions have been found, or so it seems.That’s produced victories over Morton and St Mirren that have lted spirits among Arabs. Rightly so, because both outings have seen impressive work.Of course, with most of those brought in lacking match fitness – that’s usually the major issue with January signings – the good football, has mostly come in the first hour.Players who’ve not had a lot of game time have tired, particularly when reduced to  men at St Mirren. They’ve then shown their ability to manage matches.What the manager also looks to have done well is identy those already in his squad who were good enough to be part of his plans.For all new boys like Peter Pawlett, Mark Reynolds and Mark Connolly have deserved the praise they’ve received for their first couple of performances, attackers Pavol Safranko and Nicky Clark have shown they remain big players.After a run of just two goals in nine games, Safranko has found his scoring touch with one in each of the last two outings and has looked the lethal striker he did when he first arrived on loan from Aalborg.Now he’s finally got fully fit, Clark also looks dangerous and there’s no doubt both have benefited from having better players round them in the last two outings.For Neilson and his players the trick is now to keep the good work going. The good news for United fans is, this time, that might just happen.

title: Council agrees budget for 2019 20
story: It says thebudget is set to deliver pound. million savings over the next three years with a "Change Fund" of pound. million set aside to help "resource and deliver the change programme".Investment of an additional and recurring pound. million for roads maintenance was also approved, with plans for how this will be spentto be brought to a future meeting of the councils development and infrastructure committee.Members also agreed to raise Council Tax by three per cent.Budget leader, Councillor Alister Mackinnon, said: ldquoOur workforce is vitally important to communities. Not just in the services they provide, but, as one of the biggest employers in Highland, council jobs are fundamental to the sustainability of many communities. So a budget for jobs is really good news for people.ldquoA key element of the feedback we received is that we have many cumbersome, complicated and bureaucratic processes. We need to do things dferently, streamlining processes, be more outward looking and adopt best practice.ldquoAn overwhelming message is that we need to be more efficient. Basically, we need to get a grip on our expenditure. As a result we have been examining every budget line and turning over every stone, to make sure that we are getting the best results from the resources being used and challenging where performance can be improved.ldquoIf you always do the same things in the same way, you will get the same results. It is time to change how we do things and so this is a budget for change."The change fund is an exciting element of our budget strategy and will underpin our programme of change over the coming year.Council leader Margaret Davidson said: ldquoThis is a decent, thoughtful and ambitious budget which will help move us into the future, protecting jobs and services."It aims to set the council on a journey of much needed change. We are all ambitious for improvement and what has struck me is the huge buy-in from all staff in challenging circumstances.ldquoThis budget will enable us to be sustainable and I am really confident that we have the necessary knowledge and expertise in our top team to take forward the change programme that is required.Chief executive Donna Manson added: ldquoThis budget process has been about us being connected. Connected to our communities, to our staff, to our partners, to each other ndash building relationships and enabling better conversations and improved understanding.ldquoI really appreciate the input from staff across the organisation during the whole engagement process, and for some really honest feedback. I am equally delighted with the really positive engagement across the political groups.ldquoWe need to manage all our resources, to redesign, to become more resilient, to be more efficient, to invest in our workforce and to plan for the future. We need to embed effective performance management and effective scrutiny.ldquoThe Corporate Plan will be coming to council in March and this will focus on scrutiny and driving performance. title: Cyclists gather pollution data in Inverness
story: CLEAN air campaigners have strapped pollution sensors onto their bikes to expose the cityrsquos toxic air hotspots.The Highland Cycle Campaign is working with a student-led research project from Cambridge University to monitor air quality near roadways because of fears official figures are not capturing ldquodangerous levels of pollution.So far six members have used the pound monitors in ious areas including the A trunk road.And there are plans to extend its reach to the rest of the Highlands.Secretary Anne Thomas, who acts as local co-ordinator for Friends of the Earth Scotland, said the devices are showing where the most polluted areas are.She said: ldquoThe first maps show pollution levels on Academy Street and at the Longman roundabout as particularly high.And she claimed that the levels did seem, in some cases, to be breaching standards ldquowhich should have been met in .She added: ldquoIn reality there is no safe level of pollution which is responsible for thousands of premature deaths a year across Scotland.Mrs Thomas hopes the findings inspire more people to cycle as studies show car drivers spend longer in toxic air than walkers or cyclists on main roads.Friday  Feb  : PM

story: A Highland seafood firm set up by an award-winning entrepreneur has gone into voluntary liquidation.Coast and Glen, founded by Magnus Houston in , had grown rapidly in recent years, supplying fresh fish and game to hotels and restaurants across the UK and had also expanded direct sales to consumers.The business, which employed nine people and had a turnover of pound. million, operated from fully-fitted leased premises in Alness and had also acquired a new  sq ft factory in Muir of Ord.Its liquidation was attributed to unsustainable cash flow problems stemming from rising costs, intense competition and very low margins.Mr Houston, a former motorcycle racer, taught himself the trade after a bad crash.His other business, Fishbox, is unaffected.Friday  Feb  : PM
