title: Iain Macwhirter  After making demands she couldn t accept  Corbyn has made Theresa May an offer she can   t refuse
story: Last week, Corbyn made a remarkable overture to the Prime Minister. He effectively dropped his opposition to her Withdrawal Agreement, which Labour had repeatedly condemned as the ldquoworst of all worlds. The Labour leaderrsquos letter still calls for a customs union, regulatory alignment on trade and guarantees on workers rights and security cooperation. But, crucially, Labour is no longer holding to the ldquosix tests, and insisting a Brexit deal should deliver ldquoexactly the same benefits as being in the single market.Labour has even dropped its opposition to the Irish backstop, which Mr Corbyn condemned, as recently as December, for leaving Britain ldquoin an indefinite halfway house with no say on its future. The explanatory note that Labour circulated after the leaderrsquos letter to May is quite clear. ldquoAny withdrawal agreement," it says, ldquowill need to include a backstop." Labour is also hinting at further compromises in ldquonegotiations.Hitherto, Labourrsquos policy has been to make demands May could never accept now they are trying to make her an offer she canrsquot refuse.So at last, after months of there being nothing much new to say about Brexit, suddenly we have what looks like a breakthrough, a historic compromise. Of course, you canrsquot overestimate the ability of political leaders to look a gt horse in the mouth. Theresa May may be so wedded to being a ldquobloody dficult womanthat she may find a way to avoid accepting Labourrsquos free hooved mammal. But the deal is there to be made.Senior Tories like Sir Oliver Letwin have welcomed the Labour offer, seeing it as a step towards a Norway-style agreement, even though it isnrsquot. Labourrsquos plan is much closer to Turkey, which is also in a customs union and accepts regulatory alignment. Brussels likes Corbyns proposals too, as a way out of hard Brexit ldquohell.Ive argued that the logic of Labourrsquos position was always to back something resembling Theresa Mayrsquos deal with the EU. It corresponds to Labourrsquos manesto commitments to leaving the EU, including the single market, and ending free movement while seeking frictionless trade. Mrs May has always supported regulatory alignment, since the ldquocommon rule book in her Chequers plan. And the backstop, remember, involves the UK remaining in the customs union until there is a future comprehensive trade deal.In what could almost have been a coordinated intervention last week, Mrs May restated in Dublin her determination to prevent a hard border in Ireland. This put the wind up the DUP, since they fear that the border might now move to the Irish Sea.It didnrsquot appeal to the hardline Brexiteers in her own party either, who are adamant that no deal is better than her bad deal. They thought it had been killed off by last monthrsquos record-breaking Commons defeat ndash but it may now live again with Labourrsquos backing.They canrsquot admit it, of course, but May and Corbyn are now speaking broadly the same language. The customs union, regulatory alignment, rights and protections etc are all matters to do with the future trade relationship with the EU, not the Withdrawal Agreement. It covers only money, citizenship and the Good Friday Agreement.The trading relationship can only be negotiated after Brexit. It is to be hammered out within the up to four years of the transition period, during which the UK remains in the single market and the customs union.Onlythere is no agreement does the backstop comes into play, and that really just extends the transition period indefinitely. May has said she will get assurances that the backstop will be time-limited, but she canrsquot get that from the European Union. If it was limited, it would no longer be a backstop.What hard Brexiteers really fear is that the transition period might lead to a soft Brexit, not a clean break ndash and they are right. What we know is that MPs will block any no-deal Brexit. Hardliners face a choice of May Corbyn or no Brexit at all.To secure a Commons majority without them, Mrs May could promise legislation to keep Britain in regulatory alignment with the customs union until a new trade deal is finalised ndash one which delivers the same benefits. This is anyway implicit in her promises to keep trade ldquofrictionless. Indeed, remaining in a customs union is the only way of achieving this. Up to now, she hasnrsquot been able to say this openly for fear of a rebellion by her hardline backbenchers, led by Jacob Rees-Mogg. They want a managed no-deal now, or in four years, under the so-called ldquoMalthouse Plan.Butshe has an ounce of political sense, May will now face them down and pivot to Labourrsquos softish Brexit. Labourrsquos demand that she put the customs union in primary legislation can be finessed, because the trade negotiations canrsquot happen until after Brexit. She doesnrsquot even need to ensure that Labour votes with her. Labour could abstain in the meaningful vote and achieve essentially the same result. The DUP would accept the customs union as a guarantee against a backstop or an east west hard border.Jeremy Corbyn could explain Labourrsquos abstention, which will be attacked by Vote Leave MPs andleader writers, by saying, as his spokespeople did last week: that the top priority ldquofor the nation is to avoid a no-deal. Corbynite commentators can be relied upon to condemn any Labour MPs who continue to vote against Mayrsquos deal as traitors. Unreconstructed Blairites, voting with the hated Moggists to force a no-deal disaster.Corbynrsquos letter made no reference to a Peoples Vote. Remainers in the Labour Party realise where all this is heading, which is why a number, like former shadow cabinet figures like Owen Smith, and Clive Lewis, have threatened to leave the party. That could become part of the script.Corbyn has used the Brexit issue to smoke out Blairite Remainers like Chuka Umunna, and the Jewish MP, Luciana Berger, in order to portray them as disloyal splitters.Of course, ordinary members of the Labour Party will be mightily confused. Many of them still think Labour is committed to a referendum. It still could come to that, of course,May doesnrsquot seize this opportunity.I still harbour vague hopes that A could be revoked, but Irsquom afraid that pro-Europeans are on the wrong side of history right now. The country is destined to leave the EU, because letrsquos face it, Labour under Jeremy Corbyn is and has always been a pro-Brexit party.And after Brexit Day  Well, get ready for Groundhog Day  as negotiations over the future EU trade deal begin all over again.

title: councils-back-their-right-to-scrap-free-school-music-tuition
story: Local authority umbrella body Cosla agreed new guidance which says elected councillors should continue to have the power to introduce or increase charges.The move comes despite a nationwide campaign to oppose spiralling fees for instrumental music tuition in Scottish schools involving leading musicians, composers and educators.The move also flies in the face of a report issued last month by the Scottish Parliamentrsquos education committee which recommended that music tuition should be free in schools.Cosla had been urged to defend free tuition - or at the very least ensure fee increases were capped to rises in inflation.However, while the new guidance acknowledges concerns over the impact of charging, it states: ldquoThe financial situation facing local authorities means many take the view that without some level of charging the sustainability of instrumental music tuition is at risk.ldquoThe provision of instrumental music tuition, and the policies adopted in terms of charging, concessions and other aspects of the service, is a matter for local democratically elected representatives who have to balance a range of priorities.The document concludes: ldquoThis guidance does not change the position that decisions about charging are a matter for local discretion including the decision to charge, the level of any charge or to apply concessions beyond those outlined in this paper.Larry Flanagan, general secretary of the Educational Institute of Scotlandteaching union, which has campaigned on the issue, said the document paved the way for the continuation of ldquounacceptable practices.He said: ldquoWe believe instrumental music is a key part of the curriculum within our comprehensive education system and should not be treated as an add-on, as it is throughout this document.ldquoThe guidance outlines very limited and short-term approaches to limiting fees or exempting certain categories of students, rather than acknowledging the need for sufficient investment to guarantee free access to instrumental music for all young people.ldquoThere is growing evidence that the introduction of charges is having a serious impact on levels of uptake, with young people from less affluent backgrounds being most likely to miss out on the opportunity to learn music.Mr Flanagan, who has written to Cosla to express his concerns, called for local authorities to show ldquocollective leadership to defend key services rather than overseeing ldquodeath by a thousand cuts.Music instructor Alastair Orr, who took part in the Holyrood inquiry,also hit out at the guidance.He said: "Coslas guidance to local authorities continues to show their indference to the plight of pupils and their parents who face paying exorbitant and unaffordable levels of fees to access instrumental and vocal tuition in Scotlands schools."Education Secretary John Swinney must challenge this monolithic thinking and encourage Cosla to acknowledge that this situation must end."However, Stephen McCabe, Coslarsquos children spokesman, defended the new guidance and said it would ensure greater consistency in support for poorer pupils.He said: ldquoAll local authorities are having to make very dficult budgetary choices on a wide range of services including instrumental music tuition.ldquoCharging for services is an important part of that decision making which can ensure that a service is sustainable. Nevertheless, no local authority makes the decision to introduce or increase charges for any service lightly, but with another extremely challenging budget it is an option that councils have to consider.ldquoThe guidance also points to good practice and consideration of the impact and potential unintended consequences of charging policies and reflects our decision there should be no charges for pupils eligible for free school meals or those sitting Scottish Qualications Authority exams.The guidance has been backed by Scotlands  local authorities and will now be discussed further with the sector and the Scottish Government.There was also support for the guidance from John Wallace, chairman of the Music Education Partnership Group, whichhas been discussing it with councils.He said: "It expands on concessions and gives examples of solutions to problems and pitfalls to avoid."In my meetings with council leaders and directors of education across the country I have been impressed at their passion for maintaining their music services despite multiple financial constraints and the introduction of charging in many authorities to maintain services."The per capita public spend on instrumental music education in Scotland through local authorities is many times as great as in England and we aim to keep it that way."Evidence shows rising fees have led to greater numbers of pupils dropping out of music classes.More than one-third of councils put their fees up or introduced new fees last year with the highest more than pound.Experts warn it could lead to widening of the gap between the rich and poor, with only the wealthy able to develop their talents.

title: alex-salmond-suggests-government-officials-hiding-behind-hr-overhaul
story: A spokesman for the former First Minister said top official Leslie Evans and others seemed to be ldquotrying to sub-contract their own responsibility onto their personnel department.The spokesperson said: ldquoThey should not be allowed to get away with it. The buck should stop with those in charge.It followed news that the government is spending pound, hiring consultants to help it develop an ldquoHR Transformation Strategy for its troubled People Directorate.Read more:Scottish Government to overhaul HR operation after Alex Salmond caseEdinburgh-based PA Consulting Group is due to start work on Monday on options, targets, a ldquotransformation roadmap, plus an outline business case and a detailed business case.Their task also covers ldquoHR best practice, suggesting shortcomings in the current set-up.The contract was announced a month after the collapse of the in-house probe, led by the People Directorate, into two sexual misconduct claims against Mr Salmond.After Mr Salmond challenged the process in a judicial review, it emerged the investigating officer had been in prior contact with the complainers.The defenders in the case - Permanent Secretary Ms Evans and Scottish ministers - were forced to admit that prior contact rendered the process unlawful, unfair and ldquotainted by apparent bias, which left taxpayers with a pound, legal bill.The overhaul of the governmentrsquos HR operation will look at ldquoHR services trends, and the lsquoart-of-the possiblersquo... emerging technologiesand HR lsquobest-practicersquo.Read more:Business diary of Nicola Sturgeons top aide records gym class but not Alex Salmond meetingThe People Directorate said it wanted ldquoto become a fit-for-purpose, modern, continuously improving HRthat makes the most of our people, processes and technology.A spokesperson for Mr Salmond said: ldquoIn the Court of Session case it was the decisions of the Permanent Secretary Leslie Evans as First Respondent which were found to be ldquounlawful, ldquounfair and ldquotainted by apparent bias, at a potential cost to the Scottish taxpayers of over half a million pounds. The other respondents were Scottish Ministers.ldquoThis latest development looks like they are trying to sub-contract their own responsibility onto their personnel department. They should not be allowed to get away with it. The buck should stop with those in charge.Separately, Mr Salmond last month appeared in court charged with two counts of attempted rape, nine of sexual assault, two of indecent assault and one of breach of the peace.He strongly denies any criminality.The Scottish Government rejected any linkage between its HR overhaul action and the failures exposed in Mr Salmondrsquos judicial review.A spokesperson said: ldquoThese issues are entirely unconnected. This contract is part of a three year programme to improve the digital systems for our HR service, which started in October . The business case for this phase was approved four months ago in October .ldquoWe operate a shared HR service for a number of dferent government agencies.ldquoWe are transforming the service to meet the needs of the increasing customer base and to ensure the efficiency of our processes and technology.

title: top-chefs-join-campaign-to-save-edinburgh-health-project
story: The project has provided support to vulnerable people across north Edinburgh, including some of Scotlandrsquos most deprived areas for  years. But it faces having to close next month after Edinburghrsquos health and social care body withdrew funding.The Integration Joint Boardtold the project in December that its funding would not be removed. But the decision has been greeted with bafflement by many in the north of Edinburgh who say the servicersquos blend of drop-in mental health support, support for victims of domestic abuse, childcare, cookery classes and art workshops is invaluable. Tom Kitchin and Martin Wishart said : ldquoPCHP plays a really important role in ensuring everyone can access and cook healthy, nutritious meals. Itrsquos vital that these and other services continue.The campaign says pound, will allow the project to run a much-reduced service for a year, but crucially will keep the doors open while longer-term funding is sought.A spokeswoman for the PCHP said Edinburghrsquo s IJB had also cut funding for six other charities in the north of the city ldquoThe short notice mean few will survive and itrsquos the people living in the most deprived areas of Edinburgh that will pay the price, she said.Edinburgh IJB says  grant applications for funding were received covering the next three financial years, totalling poundmillion, but it only had . million available to spend.campaign website:www.savepchp

title: modern-day-womble-is-making-good-use-of-things-that-he-finds
story: Day by day on a beach by the Firth of Clyde, resourceful pensioner Neil Hughes is fighting a battle against plastic pollution and fly-tipping by gathering washed-up refuse and things dumped by the careless to forty his little hut.The building has been in his family for almost  years, and has weathered wind, waves and rain time and time again, with any damage repaired first by Mr Hughes father George, who built the hut, and now by himself. All the materials come from the beach itself, with the Hughes family practicing recycling long before it became fashionable.Mr Hughes, , spent his childhood holidays in the beach hut near Gourock, Inverclyde, and still enjoys using it decades later.Perched on Lunderston Bay, the beach hut has been in his family for  years and is the focal point for a popular day out with the fourth generation of his family.But when hersquos not hosting barbecues with his nine grandchildren beachcomber Mr Hughes spends his time cleaning the area and putting any rubbish to good use.Just like the fictional Wombles who roamed Wimbledon Common in the s looking for junk, Mr Hughes scours the beach for discarded items he can reuse to heat and cook in the little outbuilding.He dries out bits of drtwood to put in the Rayburn cooker, and is using scrap metal left by an unscrupulous builder to repair a seawall which protects the hut from the elements.His efforts also stretch to removing bits of glass and plastic from the beach which simply blight the landscape, disposing of them so it does not harm marine le.However, the father-of-three, from Inverkip, said the problem with littering has become much worse in recent years.He said: ldquoWe have had this beach hut for  years. When my father died I took over the hut and Irsquom down there most days.ldquoI always make sure that I pick up litter ndash therersquos a lot of it washed ashore, from off boats, things like plastic bottles andtimber.ldquoIf itrsquos wood I use it to heat the hut, for the fire. If itrsquos plastic, I put it in my own bin. Therersquos some good timber washed up off boats so Irsquoll dry it out and use it for fuel."Mr Hughes built a seawall but a bad storm a few months ago damaged it. He is now busy putting up a new one, using metal cages and bits of scaffolding.Neil added: ldquoThe stuff at the hut will be used to repair the breakwater.ldquoOn the missives, it tells you that you can make the hut watertight to protect it from the elements.ldquoMy son is helping me and once the breakwater is built I will fill it with boulders from the beach.ldquoIrsquove got an area where I dry timber so I can use it for fuel. It is really just recycling.A former shipyard worker, he is used to getting his hands dirty and putting in a dayrsquos hard work to get the job done, and is pleased to be doing something to protect the environment. And the little hut is proving a hit with the youngest members of his family, suggesting it will be a long time yet before it loses its battle with the sea.Mr Hughesrsquos we Mary also enjoys going to the peaceful coastal beauty spot, and their grandchildren love having barbecues at the hut.However, it cannot be used for overnight stays due to not having sanitation.Mr Hughes added: ldquoWhen my grandchildren visit, they donrsquot want to go home. Wersquove got to drag them off the beach ndash they love the fires, and people passing by.ldquoItrsquos amazing ndash people of all nationalities that walk by. People are always telling me it looks lovely.ldquoThey are amazed at how clean and tidy it is. If therersquos stuff on the beach, I use it or dispose of it.ldquoIrsquom there winter and summer, making sure the place is secure and left spotlessly tidy.

title: letters-let-us-have-a-seats-based-formula-for-agreeing-on-another-referendum
story: The demand for further referendums has to be visible, credible, measurable and also legitimate. Your correspondent Peter A Russellpoints us in the right direction ndash ldquorational and pragmatic discussion for the best possible outcomes in the governance of the country, although I struggle to agree with him that this was reflected in the early days of the Scottish Parliament under Labour dominance. It should be possible for Westminster and Holyrood to agree a legal framework for the setting in motion of future legitimate referendums. The most logical way to agree on the granting of a new referendum is a formula based on seats held in Holyrood or Westminster or both with a specic time lapse between referendums.Theresa May previously said ldquonow is not the time for another Scottish independence referendum. It is a disgraceful dismissal by one person on a critical issue, the granting of which does not bring independence but simply a vote on it. If there is continued refusal to agree a framework for Scotlandrsquos way forward, an existing sense of frustration in the way Westminster is treating Scotland can only deepen, and who knows where that will lead Alan M Morris, Kirkhouse Road, Blanefield, Glasgow.THE normally-astute Iain Macwhirter misconceives the nature of the Union, and exaggerates the Supreme Courtrsquos pronouncements on Holyrood .The point of a constitution is to limit the day-to-day power of government. A sovereign Westminster means the UK has none. Any constitution which enshrined the inisibility of the UK would have rendered unlawful both the Good Friday Agreementand the Edinburgh Agreement .Spain is irrelevant. It does have aconstitution which, according to Madrid, prohibits Catalonian secession. That might be tested in the current notorious criminal trial, and subsequently perhaps in the European Court of Justice, where I hope Madrid will fail, because the constitution itself is woolly, and because Catalonia is a fit polity for independenceits people so choose.We should not fixate on a referendum under the Scotland Act. Section  is simply a procedure for the Privy Council to give Holyrood a power which it does not normally have: a mechanism, which thereby s within the terms of UK domestic law, for ascertaining the will of the Scottish electorate.In constitutional terms, however, the mechanism is not important. What is important, for a decision on independence to gain international recognition, is that it be legitimate, democratic and peaceful.If S was the only method by which Scotland could make the choice, that would have the necessary but absurd consequence that evenevery single resident from Unst to the Mull of Galloway wanted independence, London could prevent it by autocratic diktat. That would be absurd self-evidently, and because no UK government maintains that the Union persists by anything but consent.If Scotland withdraws that consent by a legal, democratic and peaceful decision, by whatever means, its exit from the Union cannot be legitimately frustrated. No absurd legal restrictions set up within the Union can operate to prevent such a Scottish exit, because the move to independence is of a higher order.A referendum under Section  should be tried again, not because of any inherent advantage, but because that was how Scotland rejected independence in , and reversing that decision should ideally use the same process.But Londonrsquos refusal would open the way for other acceptable means, such as an election under a clear and direct manesto of independence, on which London would have no say whatsoever.Accordingly, when the Scottish Government seeks permission for a fresh referendum, it should state thatpermission is not forthcoming within a certain time, the alternative route of an election will be taken. That would be unimpeachable, and the warning itself might be enough to wring agreement from London.It is a waste of breath to blame Scotlandrsquos non-independence on anyone but ourselves. The means are in our own hands entirely. All we have to do to show we are worthy of independence is to choose it.Alan Crocket, Leyland Road, Motherwell.THE  Scottish independence referendum campaign woke up, and lit up, Scotland. There was a flowering of political debate theand breadth of the country as people got involved in the campaign, many of whom had never before taken part in political campaigning, and there were vibrant public meetings held all over Scotland with town halls and community centres filled to overflowing. I do not recognise Peter A Russells description of the referendum campaign as being "that bruising and isive episode" I voted Yes, I have friends who voted No, and were still friends.Politics is isive, but presenting a distorted version of the events of the  campaign, which despite a few incidents on both sides, was overwhelmingly well conducted, is not only misleading, but insulting to the Scottish public, and smacks of the increasing desperation of many Unionists who know they are losing the argument.Ruth Marr, Grampian Road, Stirling.ROBERT IG Scottraised the important issue of the lack of respect shown to the questioner by the SNP at First Ministers Questions. It seems to be policy to attack and deride the question and the questioner. Presumably this is a deliberate approach to avoid actually answering the question asked.If I was in opposition I would simply announce at the start of Question Time that I would not be asking any questions as, based on past experience, there is little or no prospect of an answer being given. The SNP talks about respect without actually showing any.Jim Hamilton, Waterside Gardens, Carmunnock, Glasgow.

title: theresa-may-is-a-just-about-managing-jam-prime-minister
story: Both Jeremy Corbyn and Theresa May are united in shared opining on jam. Jam as in edible preserve, not as in the jam in which we currently find ourselves.Incapable of cooking up a cohesive formula as to how to get us out of the sticky mess that is Brexiting Britain, Mrs May has been revealed to be capable of a type of rank frugality in the store cupboard, which, presumably, she intends the rest of the country to assume once wersquore living on corned beef and tinned potatoes.Or, Spam and canned peaches, as the chairman of Tesco, John Allan, told ITVrsquos Robert Peston this week. Asked how supermarkets will cope in the event of a no-deal Brexit, Mr Allan replied: "We can build up stores of long -le food, and provided wersquore happy to live on Spam and canned peaches, all will be well.Mrs May, it was leaked, told a Cabinet meeting she scrapes the top from mouldy jam and makes it Brexit Secretary. Sorry, bins it and eats whatrsquos underneath.But perhaps Mrs May is confused with Jam families. Remember the acronym du jour circa   As is the rage with politicians, Mrs May chose a demographic to target ndash in this case, ldquojust about managing upper working class and lower middle class families ndash and promised to target policies at making their lives easier. Now we have a just-about-managing Prime Minister.One of the specic attributes of the Jams was low resilience to economic shocks. Still, just scrape the mould off, eh This controversy is not the first time conserve has left a party leader in a sweet stew. Mr Corbyn, who, yoursquoll remember, makes his own jam, generated outraged headlines in  with the admission that he doesnrsquot like strawberry. ldquoNice kids, terrible taste in jam, he tweeted of a bunch of youngsters from a childrenrsquos centre in Leyland, Lancashire, who had been hoodwinked into baking cupcakes with the Labour leader.Mr Corbynrsquos fruit mix of choice  Apple and blackberry.An interesting choice. At first glance, a bit uppity, a bit not of the people. But look again. Strawberries donrsquot come cheap, while blackberries and apples can be foraged for free from Great British highways and byways. Presuming yoursquove stockpiled some sugar, this might be something to bear in mind come March .As we deal with a global environmental crisis, a debate between the importance of inidual choices and the necessity of forcing corporations to make more environmentally sound choices rages on.Mrs May is leading from the front, telling us, a patient public, that food shouldnrsquot be binned because itrsquos past its best-before date. Shoppers, she apparently said, should use ldquocommon sense. Given the gobsmacking lack of sense ndash common or otherwise ndash being demonstrated by the Prime Minister or any of her party, this appears cheek of a dizzyingly high level.She has a point, though, and it is here I must confess I find myself, for the first time, entirely simpatico with Theresa. It is rare indeed that I eat in-date food. Irsquom still using spaghetti with a  date on it, to no ill effect.I eat out of date fruit and veg, milk and eggs well past the sell-by stamps. Still here.Mould, though, is another matter. The spores tend to infect an item entirely and merely scraping the visible rot away will do little to make the entity safe for consumption. Therersquos a metaphor there.As a Conservative, itrsquos predictable that Mrs May is suggesting that successfully enduring the ills of a Brexit food shortage will fall to the inidual and their ingenuity in stretching their single egg ration to last a family of five. As Mr Allan might say, every little helps.But therersquos something tragicomic about the Prime Ministerrsquos advice. Much as she tries to make herself relatable to the general populace, an ordinary woman, scraping her jam in a field of wheat, she appears as one computer-generated by an alien race whose research of Earthlings extended only to reading a Wikipedia page on humans with ldquocitations needed.Appearing on the One Show with husband Phillip in , Mrs May was quick to explain that chores in her household are ided into ldquoboy jobs and girl jobs.Mr May described how the home is run. ldquoWell, he said, ldquoI get to decide when I take the bins out. NotI take them out.The clue to the main property of jam is in its alternate name -ndashpreserve. Itrsquos designed to last. If Mrs Mayrsquos jam is being left long enough to turn mouldy then surely itrsquos a sign that she is unsuited to jam, jam is not for her. Her jam, which she committed to buying, has gone off thanks to disinterest.She is more like toast: done.

title: half-of-herald-readers-refuse-to-watch-question-time-poll-reveals
story: The poll, completed by  readers, showed that % decided not to watch the show after criticism over former Coatbridge and Chryston UKIP candidate Billy Mitchells fourth appearance.Eighteen per cent said they would tune it, while % revealed they hadnt watch the show in years.Read more:Question Time row: BBC reject accusations of bias after backlash over UKIP candidateIt comes as the BBC"rejected accusations that last weekrsquos audiencewas not representative of a range of views", saying they would not normally allow someone to appear againthey had featured "recently".But he sparked online debate after he launched fiercely criticisedSNPrsquos Fiona Hyslop during last Thursdayrsquos edition of the popular topical debate programme.The makers of BBC Question Time were under more pressure on Thursday morning after it was claimed that Fiona Hysloprsquos full response to a former UKIP candidate was edited out from last weekrsquos Question Time in Motherwell.It has since been revealed that he has appeared in the showrsquos audience four times, with his last audience appearance giving him more than a minute of uninterrupted airtime to direct a rant at an SNP minister.

title: youth-strike-4-climate-thousands-of-school-pupils-walk-out-in-strike
story: The strikes will protest against the so-called inaction of governments and corporations in the face of a lsquoclimate crisisrsquo.The students will call on governments to reduce carbon emissions in line with caps decided in the Paris Climate Agreement, which comes into force next year.A second strike, coordinated across Europe, will take place next month.The lsquoYouth Strike  Climatersquo movement was inspired by the campaigning of Greta Thunberg, a -year-old student from Sweden.Thunberg stopped attending school on Fridays, using the day to picket outside the Swedish parliament and lobby for legislation limiting carbon emissions. The Scottish Greens have published an open letter to school headteachers urging them not to punish students for striking to attend demonstrations in areas including Glasgow, Ullapool, Fort William and Forres.Read more:Climate Strike comes to Scotland: Children skip school to protestHer protest soon sparked copycat demonstrations across Europe that saw around , students lsquostrikingrsquo on Fridays.Todayrsquos strikes have been organised by a coalition of youth climate change activist groups.YouthStrikeClimate, the UK Student Climate Network and the UK Youth Climate Coalition expect thousands to attend their demonstrations.They urge students online to ldquocome along and strike for our futureA Facebook event for the demonstration in George Square in Glasgow tshows almost  people lsquogoingrsquo and  lsquointerestedrsquo.The event is hosted by the Glasgow branch of Extinction Rebellion, a direct action group that uses civil disobedience to protest against an ldquounprecedented global emergency.Students in Edinburgh are not expected to strike because schools are still on holiday for Spring half term.The Scottish Greens argue today in an open letter from Ross Greer MSP, the partyrsquos education spokesman, to school leaders that that students striking from school are acting as ldquoresponsible citizens and should not be punished for attending the demonstrations.The letter reads: ldquoScotlandrsquos Curriculum for Excellence is based on the idea that we support our young people to become responsible citizens. Every school student who takes action against the climate crisis on Friday is doing exactly that.ldquoThey should know that they will not be punished for defending their own future. They have the Scottish Greensrsquo support and I hope they will have the support of their teachers and education authorities.ldquoThe scientic evidence of a climate crisis is clear. The latest report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change says that the world will see catastrophic impacts evencountries managed to limit warming to just . degrees Celsius, a target we are not close to reaching.Read more:Climate change school strike by -year-old Scottish pupilldquoGovernments, including here in Scotland, need to act even faster than previously agreed.ldquoYoung people have every right to be angry that their future is being destroyed by the inaction, complacency and greed of todayrsquos leaders.Jim Thewliss, General Secretary of School Leaders Scotland, said that while schools have legal obligations and duty of care, and must record unauthorised absences from school, he would ldquonot expect there to be a punishment element to this.ldquoIt says a lot about the Scottish education system and Scottish society in general that Scottish people feel strongly enough about this issue to protest, he told The Herald.ldquoWe as an organisation could not support not going to school. To our mind there are better ways of doing this.ldquoBy law we are obliged to record students not being in school and we would inform their parents.ldquoWe have a duty of care. There may be a signicant number of students protesting legitimately but we would be negligent of that duty to not inform parents.Striking in Scotland  Send your photos to the Herald newsdesk.

title: in-full-bbc-send-letter-to-scottish-mps-and-msps-defending-question-time
story: The letter was issued after a former UKIP candidateBilly Mitchell appeared on the popular politics show on Thursdaynight when it aired from Motherwell, North Lanarkshire.Mitchellclaimed that he was invited by the shows producer to appear in the unionist-heavy audience in Motherwell last week, in part to make up a shortage of conservative speakers.:Half of Herald readers refuse to watch Question Time, poll revealsA Herald poll of over , readers found that over half would refuse to watch BBC Question Time following the show in Motherwell.In an emailed letter seen by The National,Ian Small, BBCScotlands head of public policy  corporate affairs addressed the criticism.The letter in full:Dear all,Following concerns expressed about the recent edition of BBC Question Timeand also the repeated appearance of an audience member, I thought you would be interested in some further information. The programme included a range of opinions and the discussions were, as always, lively and robust.Audience selectionThe audience in Motherwell was selected in line with our guidelines to reflect support for ious political parties and viewpoints.Our procedures for audience selection are thorough and we make every effort to prevent people from appearing more than once. We ask applicantsthey have been on the programme before, but of course, rely on people providing accurate information.We are aware there have been questions surrounding one member of the audience in last weekrsquos programme. When selecting audiences we take the information they provide in good faith, as you would expect. On previous occasions, the inidual concerned has not provided accurate information to the programme and that is the reason they were able to appear on the programme again. We will continue to keep our processes under review and make every effort to make sure we get the best possible audience for each programme. Our primary concern is to balance the audience.:Question Time row: BBC reject accusations of bias after backlash over UKIP candidateThe programme does not, of course, approach audience members and invite them to appear, as has also been alleged in some quarters, but will often contact audience members to provide further verication, again relying on the veracity of the information provided.Accusations of lsquosecret editingrsquoThere was no lsquosecret editingrsquo as has been claimed in some media outlets and on social media of what the Cabinet Secretary, Fiona HyslopMSP said. Immediately following the Cabinet Secretaryrsquos full response to a question from an audience member, the audience member interjected and made a comment that could not be broadcast for legal reasons. Ms Hyslop attempted to intervene on the comment being made, and the two or three words she uttered were made at the same time that Mr Mitchell was speaking. This resulted in both briefly speaking over each other, at which point the Chair stopped the interchange and moved to a new topic and another audience question. We believe this was the only responsible thing to do in the circumstances. In any case, Ms Hysloprsquos response to the audience member on the issue of independence was broadcast in full.:Failed UKIP candidate claims he was personally invited on to BBC Question TimePlease let me assure you that Question Time takes very seriously the issue of balance on our  and in the audience. We review and discuss the make-up of every  and go to great s to reflect a broad spectrum of opinion in our audiences, and we will continue to do so.If you have any questions I will, of course, be happy to answer them.Ian..........The letter was seen by reporters at our sister paper The National

title: glasgow-designer-creates-sustainable-clothing-brand-from-used-jeans
story: So much so, that the -year-old who hails from the Southside haslaunched her own ethical fashion business, ReJean Denim.Using defective second-hand denim she sources from charity shops, vintage sellers, recycling centres and online hauls, Siobhan creates stylishworkwear jackets for men and women of all sizes and ages.As well as making the jackets, after unpicking every pair of jeans by hand, Siobhan has plans to offer workshops that will teach other crafty types how to remake their own leftover clothing.:The peacock throne: thirty years of stylish fashion in GlasgowShe said: "I want to create items that will last the test of time and get people into repairing their own clothes."Id like to teach them how to repair their own ReJean jackets rather than just tossing them into landfills."Overall, its about education as well as just being sustainable and trying to make something thats cool and wearable and high-end."According to research carried out by Zero Waste Scotland, an estimated pound million worthof used clothing goes to landfill in the UK every year - a figure that Siobhan hopes to have even the tiniest impact on.Siobhan studied fashion and textiles at Cardonald College before taking up a fashion degreein Manchester, graduating in .Her love of vintage was furthered when she started working at London vintage store, Rokit, a haunt of fashion conscious celebrities including Kate Moss, and working as a tailor for major denim retailer, Levis.She said: "I kind of had a bit of an obsession with denim. I was constantly repairing jeans and altering them."Moving back to Glasgow in  and inspired by the flourishing creative community in her home town, Siobhan set about realising her ambition of starting her own fashion enterprise.Launching two weeks ago with a stock drop - where she showcased every item available to sell -on Instagram, Siobhan sold half of her designs and sent some jackets packing to as far away as Australia and the Netherlands.She sells her stock from Colab Scotland, a creative hub based in the city centre, where buyers can buy off-the-rack or be measured for a bespoke creation.If shes being "super productive" Siobhan can make two pieces a dayshes unpicked a few pairs the night before. She has mastered the art of deconstructing the denims and can get it down to under an hour per pair.Siobhans designs have been well received and shes "loving" what shes doing.She said: "Ive had a really nice response from people which is just lovely to hear. Im just excited to see where I can go with it."As part of an online community of female makers, Siobhan is able to reach a wider audience when her work is shared by others. And she reciprocates, promoting their work to her own followers.She said: "Its so nice, people are just championing each other. I think itsyoure handmaking stuff and youve got a sustainable ethos its just about sharing and getting other people involved.":Graduates can make a dference to Scotlandrsquos environmentWith plans for a website and an expansion into making other items of clothing, including made-to-measure jeans, ReJean Denim is gaining momentum. But its not only Siobhans design and making skills that shinethrough in her range but her genuine appreciation for the materials she works with.She said: "Most of the jeans I use are re-sellable but have small defects. Some of them already have old repairs on them from a past le and Ill always try to feature that in the jacket."I just want to focus on celebrating the original details of an old pair of jeans."

title: most-scottish-labour-mps-now-back-new-brexit-vote
story: The Glasgow North East MP said he wanted a ldquoratication referendum to give voters a choice between Theresa Mayrsquos deal and stayingin the EU.The plan was floated last week by Labour MPs Peter Kyle and Phil Wilson.Mr Sweeney insisted he was not supporting the Peoplersquos Vote campaign, which he dismissed as a vague ldquoneo-liberal, Blairite project.But his position nevertheless means four of the Scottish Labours seven MPs now actively advocate another Brexit vote.The others are East Lothianrsquos Martin Whitfield, Edinburgh Southrsquos Ian Murray and Rutherglen and Hamilton West MP Ged Killen.The numbers put pressure on Scottish Labour leader Richard Leonard to spell out his position.:Scottish Labour MP says his partys Brexit policy is ludicrousMr Sweeney set out his case at an event called ldquoLove Socialism, Hate Brexit at Westminster on Thursday.He later told the Herald: ldquoIf Theresa May is not willing to compromise on her deal, thenshersquos that confident in it she should approach it the same way as the Good Friday Agreement, so there was a ratication. We give the people a final say.ldquoItrsquos not a Peoplersquos Vote. Itrsquos not about overturning any view.ldquoItrsquos about saying, this is the deal thatrsquos on offer, andyou donrsquot raty that deal then the default is to remain as we are as a member state of the European Union.He added: ldquoThe problem with the Peoplersquos Vote campaign is that itrsquos been rather patronising. I think thatrsquos put a lot of people off. Itrsquos seen as a somewhat condescending narrative from the people who actually ran the Remain campaign in the first place.ldquoWersquore saying what we want to present is a radical socialist argument for why we should be in the European Union reforming the institutions.:Fall-off in Scottish Labour membership due to natural cycle of politics, claims SweeneyA Scottish Labour source said: ldquoItrsquos fantastic that a majority of our MPs now back a final say.ldquoThere are lot of dferent groups campaigning for a referendum, but therersquos a growing consensus that the public should get a choice between Theresa Mayrsquos deal or remaining in the EU.ldquoThe only stumbling block now is the Labour leadership north and south of the Border, and itrsquos time for them to start listening.Meanwhile, Mr Murray said on Friday that Labour MPs were being "pushed to the brink" by the party leadershiprsquos refusal to throw its weight behind a second referendum.Amid speculation some Labour MPs may quit over Jeremy Corbynrsquos desire for a deal on Brexit, rather than opposing it and pushing for a second vote.Mr Murray told BBCrsquos Political Live the party had exhausted all the stages agreed by last yearrsquos conference ahead of moving to second vote, and should back one formally now.He said: ldquoThe leadership are doing everything they possibly can to stop that from happening. Thats why people are increasingly fed up. Its not just Labour MPs who are being played for fools, its the country and Labour Party members and supporters."He said Mr Corbyn and Mrs May were "pandering to the extreme wings of their own parties", warning: ldquoIf our leaders cant stand up for our national interest, then they cant have our support."Askedhe could quit Labour, he said: "Ive never considered that, but we are all being pushed to the brink with the issues around Brexit and the issues around anti-Semitism."Denying he was disloyal, he added: "My loyalty is to my constituents and to the Labour Party, who want us to move to this position that they democratically agreed. I dont believe in blind loyalty."

title: ian-murray-labour-mps-being-pushed-to-brink-by-leaderships-refusal-to-back-second-referendum
story: Ian Murray was speaking amid growing speculation that Labour MPs may quit the party out of frustration with leader Jeremy Corbyns stance on EU withdrawal.:Ian Murray: Theresa May must recognise Brexit lsquoshamblesrsquo will not pass and come up with a new planFormer frontbencher Chuka Umunna said on Thursday he did not "give a damn... about keeping any party together" when compared to the overriding priority of the national interest in avoiding a no-deal Brexit.And ex-shadow chancellor Chris Leslie told the House of Commons Labour supporters are being "played for fools" by a leadership which would not put into effect a motion passed unanimously at annual conference to keep the option of a second referendum on the table.Labour says the option of a referendum does remain on the table, but Mr Corbyns focus in recent weeks has been on his five demands for a Brexit involving a customs union with the EU, close alignment with the single market and matching workplace and environmental protections.Mr Murray said the party had gone through all of the stages set out in the motion - including seeking an early election - and should now formally move to backing a so-called Peoples Vote."The leadership are doing everything they possibly can to stop that from happening," he told BBCs Politics Live. "Thats why people are increasingly fed up.":Ian Murray: Tories as big a threat to the union as SNPHe said "a lot" of Labour MPs are "fed up" with the leadership position on Brexit and on anti-Semitism.He added: "Its not just Labour MPs who are being played for fools, its the country and Labour Party members and supporters."There is a very solid party policy on the table at the moment that was agreed at party conference - and shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer took a standing ovation when he mentioned a Peoples Vote with an option to Remain."Its what Labour voters, Labour supporters, Labour members want, its what the country is increasingly looking at to try to break the impasse in Parliament."We have to move as quickly as possible, with  days left, to the position of a Peoples Vote with the option to Remain, because we believethe leader of the opposition backs it and whips it, we can win it and then we can try to get out of this Brexit mess."Mr Murray said both Mr Corbyn and Prime Minister Theresa May are "pandering to the extreme wings of their own parties".He added: "At some point someone is going to have to stand up and do what is in the national interest, and neither leader of any party at the moment is doing that."If our leaders cant stand up for our national interest, then they cant have our support."The Edinburgh South MP said: "If my constituents start losing their jobs on the basis that the Labour Party has facilitated a hard Conservative Brexit, on the basis that they have refused to implement a democratically put-forward motion of Labour Party conference, then we will all have to make our own decisions about whether or not that is in the best interests of the party or the country."Askedhe could quit Labour, he replied: "Ive never considered that, but we are all being pushed to the brink with the issues around Brexit and the issues around anti-Semitism."He rejected suggestions he is being disloyal to Mr Corbyn."My loyalty is to my constituents and to the Labour Party, who want us to move to this position that they democratically agreed," said Mr Murray. "I dont believe in blind loyalty."Mr Umunna was asked on Thursday whether he would quit LabourMr Corbyn refuses to back a second referendum.The Streatham MP replied: "The job of leaders is to keep the party together. Its not my job, its the leaderships job."When I joined the Labour Party, I intended to be a member on my death-bed. Ultimately whether we keep the party together is a matter for the leadership."If the leadership of either party reverts to making party political decisions instead of pursuing the national interest, then they will never, ever be forgiven."

title: virtual subsea work for meldrum pupils
story: Meldrum Academy pupils have taken part in OPITO#s Energise Your Futureevent.The academy was one of eight north east schools to have taken part in the initiative that was held during the final day of Subsea Expo at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centre on Thursday, February .EYF is managed by OPITO, the global, not-for-profit, skills body for the energy industry.The event aims to inspire and encourage more young people in the UK to consider the industry as a career choice by providing a chance to get up close with key companies and people who can help explain their businesses as well as roles and routes into the sector.This year,  companies were involved in the Subsea Expo programme.Marine engineering firm EC-OG offered pupils the chance to use its latest virtual reality technology which will transport them subsea to inspect its subsea power hub and battery equipment.John McDonald, OPITO CEO, said: “As more and more oil and gas companies embrace new techniques such as title: farmers invited to getting greener grass event
story: Soil Association Scotland is inviting farmers to a free event with pasture expert Andre van Barneveld to find out how to prepare for the grazing season ahead.Feed stocks may be low due to the extreme weather conditions last year, but are there any management options that could help maximise spring pasture production Andre van Barneveld of Graise Consultancy says that although there is no silver bullet, there are things you can do to make the most of your pasture.“My approach revolves around rotational grazing,” he says.“Grazing stimulates grass growth, butyou have all the stock on all the grass all of the time it doesn’t work – the grass needs time to recover.”He says nitrogen fertiliser can be used in a minimal way to reduce costs as well as environmental impact.“There’s no point putting it on before grazing as nitrogen can’t stimulate grass growththere’s no growth there – you’d be wasting your money.”And there is attention to be paid long term to soil health.“Rotational grazing is better for soils in the long term because it improves root structure, which gives you better grass. It’s all linked in.“It’s about truly understanding the value of grass. If you value it, and you manage it through the season it can have a real impact on profitability.”Knowledge Transfer Specialist at QMS, Emily Grant, said: “Spring grass is hugely valuable to any livestock system, whether for lambing ewes, calving cows or growing youngstock. Making the most of it will help to not only keep feed and housing costs in check, but also set up high quality pastures for the rest of the grazing season.”The event will be held on Tuesday, February  atThainstone Agricultural Centre, Inverurie from –pm.It is free to farmers and land managers but booking is required.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"MasterChef stars John Torode and Spencer Matthews will attend this years Taste of Grampian"  MasterChef stars for Taste of Grampian viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"To book visit www.soilassociation.org, call Lyn on   or email lwhite@soilassociation.org.Come along and find how you can get more from your grazing season.

title: inspectors praise north east nursery
story: Education inspectors have expressed confidence in the ongoing improvements being made at Rothienorman Pre-School Nursery.A recent visit led to the village hall facility being described as a “welcome and nurturing environment” and Inspectors said children were “happy, enthusiastic, and developing confidence”.Key strengths included a “dedicated team” which inspectors said have developed positive relationships and a “strong sense of community”.But the nursery has been asked to improve in certain areas, including increased use of national guidance to develop a “robust and rigorous approach to self-evaluation”. title: masterchef stars for taste of grampian
story: Organisers of the annual Taste of Grampian event at Thainstone have announced this year#s celebrity chefs.At a special launch event Taste of Grampian chairman, John Gregor, revealed that MasterChef star John Torode will headline the th anniversary event on Saturday, June .Chef John said: “I’ve heard the produce in the north-east is some of the best to come out of Scotland.“I’m looking forward to finding some new food and drink producers and using their ingredients in my dishes on the day.”Joining John on the day will be reality TV star Spencer Matthews, who was a surprise finalist in Celebrity MasterChef last year.He will be demonstrating on the day as well as joining John for the main highlight of Taste of Grampian – a joint demonstration.Completing the MasterChef line-up for this year will be Scotland’s national chef, Gary Maclean who was crowned the winner of The Professionals title in .Gary will be demonstrating with Scotch Beef at this year’s eventand supported by Quality Meat Scotlandwho will be the main title sponsor.Also joining the celebrity line-up will be Helen Vass, who was part of the winning team of BBC’s Bake Off Crème de la Crème in . The award-winning pastry chef will be showcasing her baking skills at several demonstrations throughout the day.Commenting at the launch of Taste of Grampian Mr Gregor said: “This is an unmissable event in the Aberdeenshire calendar.“Whether you are a complete foodie or something of a novice chef, it’s a great way of showcasing an eclectic mix of new and established food and drink producers in the area.“We’re delighted to confirm a stellar celebrity line-up with John Torode, Spencer Matthews, Gary Maclean and Helen Vass and we look forward to celebrating our th anniversary in style.”data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.hawick-news webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Aberdeenshire East MSP Gillian Martin"  Constituents urged to get blood pressure checks viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Early bird tickets for Taste of Grampian  are available to purchase online now at www.eventbrite.

story: A north-east charity has announced plans for a unique music-themed lunch event, to raise funds for its cancer support services.The CLAN Jukebox Lunch is the first of its kind, where, after enjoying a welcome glass of fizz, guests will be asked to choose their favourite tunes, which will be played throughout the afternoon.The  CLAN Jukebox Lunch will take place on Friday, May  at the Marclfe Hotel and Spa.In , over  men and women attended the annual event, which raised £, for CLAN’s cancer support services.During the afternoon in May, there will be a raffle and auction, live entertainment and a two-course lunch provided by the hotel’s renowned chefs. Guests will also be treated to a unique shopping experience, where local crafts people will showcase artworks, gts and clothing items.The popular fundraising lunch, which is sponsored by BP, promises to be a fantastic afternoon of music, shopping, entertainment and friendship.Steph McCann, CLAN Cancer Support’s Fundraising Team Manager, said: “The CLAN Lunch is one of CLAN’s most popular annual events, and we are excited to be adding a new theme this year where guests can request their favourite songs.“The Marclfe Hotel and Spa is an invaluable supporter of CLAN, and this event, with an even wider range of shopping stalls and entertainment, looks set to be the best yet.“CLAN is enormously grateful to our sponsor, BP, which enables us to ensure that every penny raised during the event will come directly to CLAN, helping to support anyone affected by a cancer diagnosis in the heart of communities throughout north-east Scotland, Moray, Orkney and Shetland."The CLAN lunch is always very popular, so we would encourage people to book their place now to avoid missing out.”Tickets for the CLAN Lunch, which will run from am to pm, are priced at £ each and are available inidually or as tables of , and can be purchased by visiting www.clanhouse.org or via the charity’s fundraising team by calling   or email fundraising@clanhouse.org.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.buchanobserver webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Unison wants talks with the council over the threat to jobs"  Unison seeks talks over council job cuts viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "BUCH | Article Teaser"

title: the top six questions people are asking google about brexit
story: Heres the answers to your questions:What is the new Brexit Party, which has been supported by Nigel Farage What is the new Brexit Party and how do I join The Brexit Party was launched with the support of ex-UKIP leader Nigel Farage in January and recognised as an official party at the beginning of February . It is a pro-Brexit party. Farage has said he will stand as an MEP under the partythe UK does not leave the EU orArticle  is extended. An official website is coming soon, and you should be able to sign up then, but in the meantime you can search for Brexit Party UK on Facebook.Will my passport be valid after Brexit Theres no need to do anything until your current passport is ready for renewal. British passports will change after we leave the EU, with blue and gold passports making afrom October , but youll still be able to travel on your old burgundy passport until it runs out. If theres a no deal Brexit, youll need to have at least six months left on your passport to travel to an EU country. If you renewed your passport before it expired, then any extra months wont count either - your passport should not be any older than nine years and six months when you travel. What is ERG This stands for the European Research Group, which is a group of pro-Brexit Conservative MPs chaired by Jacob-Res Mogg. It is lobbying on issues surrounding Brexit. The group was in the news as it is expected to rebel against todays House of Commons motion which asks MPs to reiterate its support for renegotiating the controversial Irish backstop.Read more: Will UK workers lose their rights and entitlements after Brexit Will EHIC still be valid At the minute,we fall sick or get injured while visiting the EU, then we can access the same free or discounted medical care that is available to residents of that country. The European Health Insurance Cardproves your eligibility. Regardless of the deal reached, the government will need to renegotiate the reciprocal healthcare arrangements. At the minute, a bill called HealthcareBill is being passed through Parliament to help reach such an arrangement. It is important as the scheme provides healthcare for an estimated , UK expats living in the EU as well as  million UK residents who travel abroad to EEA countries each year Until a new initiative is in place, you should check what the agreement is with the country youre visiting as EHIC may not be valid. Make sure you have travel insurance too .Will I need a visa for my holiday Not for short-term stays for holidays or business purposes. This is providing the UK offers the same deal for EU citizens who want to visit us. We will, however, have to to pay a fee to visit Europe after Brexit. From , youll need to fill in a ETIAS application form so other countries can check youre not a security threat. This is similar to the US ESTA scheme. story: The development of Inverurie#s Ury Riverside Park has taken a major step forward with a funding award of over #,.A total of £, was awarded from the LEADER fund, set up to support rural development, and will be used to undertake a wide range of planting within the site.The contract for the planting has been awarded to Aberdeenshire-based CR Contracting North Ltd, which has already done work around the park.Company Director Chris Rogerson said: “We’re really pleased to have been awarded this contract for planting – we also recently constructed the path network, so we are happy to continue with the further development of the park.“Our plan is to complete the path network, then to plant the wet woodland, grassland and wetland meadow areas.“Assuming the weather is favourable we aim to complete the works by winter next year.”The development of the park is managed by a local charity, Ury Riverside Park SCIO.Trustee of the Ury Riverside Park charitable organisation, Claire Maycock, said: “It’s great to see the area develop.“We recently held a volunteer day and planted , trees, so further planting will really enhance the site and make it feel more like a park.”Chair of the Garioch Area Committee, Fergus Hood, added: “This is great news for the Inverurie area, the development of the park is really exciting, and the award of this most recent funding will help move forward with the plans.”European funding programme LEADER allocates cash grants to projects which contribute to key themes identied in Local Development Strategies, such as connectivity, business competitiveness, the environment and people and place.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: volunteer plea for community companions
story: Royal Voluntary Service is looking for volunteers to become Community Companions, a scheme which offers practical support to older people in Inverurie.Tracey Peden, Community Development Operations Manager at Royal Voluntary Service said: “We are initially looking for one or two volunteer coordinators and volunteers to support the scheme in Inverurie, but there is scope to develop the Community Companions service across Aberdeenshire.“Our volunteers find they get as much out of volunteering as they put in it’s incredibly rewarding for them and they make a real dference to the lives of the people they support.“Those who sign up can choose to dedicate as much or as little time to volunteering as they like and full training will be given.”Community Companions volunteers offer the practical help that can make all the dference to older people and help them retain their independence– from assisted shopping and activity programmes, to enabling them to get out and about with community transport. Volunteers also provide company and companionship, while making sure the older person is safe and well.Royal Voluntary Service is one of Britain’s largest volunteering charities with over , volunteers supporting thousands of people each month in hospitals, at home and in the community.To find out more about becoming volunteer call   or email tracey.hann@royalvoluntaryservice.org.uk.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.milngavieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Level Crossing Manager Michael Burnett, Shaun McCabe, PC Derek Jackson and Lauren McCreedy of Network Rail"  Driving voucher win for Inverurie pupil viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: Caithness to get firts vegan BB
story: A BED and breakfast with a dference is to be launched in Caithness next month.Barbara and Peter Gray, who live in Berriedale, will be opening what is thought to be the first vegan BB in the far north and the venture is already attracting interest online from people throughout the UK.The couple moved to Caithness in September after purchasing a property in the village.They come from Derbyshire but spent some time in Lincolnshire before moving to Golspie and then to Caithness.They say they both like the Highlands and wanted to set up a vegan bed and breakfast here.Barbara explained: ldquoWe saw the property at The Braes in Berriedale was up for sale last summer, put in an offer and it was accepted.ldquoAt present, we have a king size double en suite room but would hope to expand and have two to three rooms later.ldquoAs far as I know we are the only vegan BB in Caithness. I think the nearest one to us may be in Aviemore.ldquoFor a long time we have wanted to provide luxury accommodation and cooking for vegans but we will also show people how to cook vegan meals and may do workshops on an ad hoc basis as well as hosting special s for events such as Valentines Day and Burns Nights.ldquoWe will be open for business in March but are already getting interest online from people in the UK and hope eventually to generate interest in Europe and the USA.Asked what would happensomeone who is not a vegan wanted to stay at the BB, she replied: ldquoThey would have to take vegan food as we do not have animal products on the premises.ldquoWe live a vegan lestyle and would prefer vegans to stay here but they donrsquot have to be vegans.Her husband Peter helps run the business but is also a writer.He has been writing for many years but in  started work on a series of crime fiction books whose main character is Detective Inspector James Avalon. The police officer is based in Inverness but travels throughout the Highlands.Friday  Feb  : PM

title: Call goes out for transport review in Thurso
story: A COMPREHENSIVE transport review is required in Thurso, according to a local Highland councillor.Karl Rosie made the plea this week after the issue of speeding and parking was raised at a meeting of the local community council.Chairman Mike Potts noted that a  mph restriction is planned for large sections of Wick and wondered what was happening in Thurso. He said some areas of the town, such as Shore Street and Upper Ormlie, had been designated as one-way streets some time ago but this had not been implemented. "That needs to be corrected," he said at Tuesday nights meeting.Mr Potts and other community councillors felt something had to be done to address the issue of speeding and one suggestion was for more sleeping policemen to be installed in problem areas of Thurso.Councillor Rosie, who represents Thurso and Northwest Caithness on Highland Council, said what is needed is a transport review which can take a comprehensive look at the issue. "We need a strategic look at the whole thing ndash something which covers transport management and pedestrians," he said.However, community councillor and former police officer Bert MacLeod urged caution. He said: "You need to be careful you dont go overboard with this  mph limit. Modern cars can stop quicker than vehicles did in the past. We need to be sensible."Mr Potts claimed "some of the driving in Thurso is abysmal".Mr MacLeod replied: "Why should you and I be affected because someone drives like an idiot "He also pointed out there are problems with installing sleeping policemen on roads. New laws have been introduced as cars have been damaged by them, he said."It is not just a case of putting them down," stated Mr MacLeod. He argued that enforcement is the key to tackling the problem."If you had a traffic warden in each town again that would help," he added.Community councillor Colin Johnston said something should be done to address the issue of traffic and parking in the town.Struan Mackie, another Thurso and Northwest Caithness Highland councillor, stressed that it takes time to process traffic orders and pointed out that the mph plan for Wick began over two years ago.He also pointed out that the county is going to get traffic enforcement officers which should help deal with some of the parking issues.Mr MacLeod commented: "You have got to watch you do not overdo these things."But Mr Potts said: "Parking has been an issue for a long time. It is up to us to keep fighting. There is parking available in the town so the problem can be overcome. That should be our war cry all the time."Friday  Feb  : PM

title: Flexibility plea on new GP deal
story: THE problems facing GPs in Caithness have been outlined to Scotlandrsquos health secretary Jeane Freeman by two north MSPs.Rhoda Grant and David Stewart.Labour representatives for the Highlands and Islands, met with Ms Freeman to express their concern about the new GP contract and the impact it could have on rural and remote areas.They were accompanied by Phil Wilson, a professor of primary care and rural health at the University of Aberdeen and a GP in Inverness.Also present was a Dingwall GP Miles Mack.Mrs Grant asked Ms Freeman for the face-to-face meeting at the Scottish Parliament and highlighted issues which GPs across the Highlands and Islands have raised with her and Mr Stewart.The doctors told the minister that five of the  permanent GPs in Caithness are likely to retire in the next five years.Ms Freeman heard that since  almost half of all permanent GP posts in the county have been vacant and partially replaced with short-term locum provision.Three practices have ceased to be independent contractors and have been taken over by NHS Highland.Concerns were also raised about the capacity for undergraduate teaching and the effect on retention and recruitment of GPs in remote areas.Doctors have told the MSPs that the new contract fails to recognise the workload in rural areas where surgeries deal with a far greater range of medical problems, including emergencies that would be dealt with in hospitals in urban areas.Mrs Grant said: ldquoThe main concern is that whatrsquos on the table with the new contract is an urban model and this just doesnrsquot suit remote and rural areas.ldquoGPs are worried it will cause poor continuity of care for patients and that procedures currently performed at surgeries are being centralised ndash for instance for blood tests or vaccinations.ldquoThis will inevitably inconvenience patients and worsen health outcomes by raising barriers to care.ldquoThe contract states that other healthcare professionals will be employed to deal with these extra tasks ndash but with rural GP posts remaining unfilled, and shortages of nurses in many areas, how can we expect to find these extra people in our out-of-the-way places ldquoThere must be flexibility for GPs to retain the old system of care.The new contractrsquos funding formula has been based on the number of appointmentsand does not take account of the issues faced by rural areas such as patient and doctor travel.ldquoGPs in our region cannot wait for another three years to see some movement on this and Irsquom hopeful that the health secretary will find a suitable way forward.At the meeting Ms Freeman said she had ldquogenuinely taken the issues seriously and discussion would continue with colleagues. Mrs Grant was promised an update in two months.Friday  Feb  : PM

title: Plans to tackle Wick town centre parking hailed as very good news
story: Local Highland councillor Andrew Sinclair said he welcomed the proposals outlined in a traffic order as they give the local authority greater powers to deal with what has been a contentious issue for many years.Many other areas of Wick would also be subject to restrictions.Councillor Sinclair, who represents the Wick and East Caithness ward, said: "I think this is very good news for the town. We have been calling for more parking enforcement in Wick for a while now."High Street and Bridge Street are far too regularly packed with cars parked where they shouldnt be. Its an issue that has been raised time and time again by both drivers and pedestrians. Some people think they are above the rules and for too long theyve got away with it."He added: "Under the current proposals Bridge Street and much of High Street will essentially become double yellows, meaning no parking at any time. This should also help stop the constant issue of people selfishly parking in areas like the Market Square."The parking bays there are intended only for those who are disabled badge holders but these rules are often ignored by people who just canrsquot be bothered walking."Councillor Sinclair said the order would give council officers the power to enforce parking restrictions once they receive the required training but, initially, existing enforcement staff would carry out the work."We should expect a much more regular presence than under the old system," he said. "The discussions Irsquove had with the officer responsible for parking have been extremely encouraging."Having an enforcement officer in the town for regular and random visits is a great start butthe situation doesnrsquot improve we will still be pushing to get someone in this post locally to clamp down on rogue drivers."He explained that in Inverness several council employees have been trained to undertake parking enforcement duties as well as their day-to-day jobs. "There is no reason why the same couldnrsquot be done up here. If these orders get the go-ahead, and I am confident they will, then I hope we will begin to see a dference in peoples behaviour."The Caithness civic leader, Councillor Willie Mackay, also backed the plan. "It is a fantastic idea but it is the enforcement that is the key to the success of this," he said. "If we can get enough staff trained up to act as traffic wardens ndash and I am pretty sure we can ndash then their presence will deter bad parking."Parking in the centre of Wick has been a contentious problem for some time and has often been raised by the local community council and others. If this is approved, it will make a massive dference to the town centre, although there will always be some motorists who will take a chance and park there."However, Councillor Mackay has misgivings about the extent of the restrictions planned for other parts of Wick.Friday  Feb  : PM

title: Prince Harry set to attend Mey games
story: THE Mey Highland Games is going to ldquoput Caithness in the global spotlight, according to its organiser Captain Richard Otley, after Prince Harry announced he would attend the event this year.Rumours were re last year that Harry and his we Meghan would attend the special event which included para-athletes for the first time but when the royal retinue appeared at pm there was no sign of the couple.Capt Otley believes that the information released over the weekend to the media about Prince Harryrsquos attendance may have come from Buckingham Palace itself. He was unable to confirmMeghan would attend along with her husband, but said it would be ldquotruly fantastic for Caithness and help put it on the mapthe royal couple turned up.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex will welcome their first child this spring.Friday  Feb  : PM
